item.title: In the news this morning: A new immigration reform bill, controversy over undocumented journalist, California Dream Act, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Robert Menendez, Senate Democrats Re-Introduce Immigration Reform Bill - Fox News Latino New Jersey Democratic Sen. Robert Menendez and other Democrats have introduced a beefed-up immigration reform bill that they hope will appeal to Republicans pushing for tougher laws. The Comprehensive Immigration Reform Act of 2011 will focus on border security, worksite enforcement, and a requirement that undocumented immigrants register with the government. I was duped by Jose Vargas, illegal immigrant : Bronstein at Large - San Francisco Chronicle Chronicle editor Phil Bronstein reflects on yesterday's widely read confession by Pulitzer winner Jose Antonio Vargas, once a Chronicle employee, that he is undocumented. 'Washington Post' Debated 'Undocumented' Reporter's Veracity - NPR Some insight into why the Washington Post, which until 2009 employed journalist Jose Antonio Vargas, passed on publishing his essay admitting that he is undocumented. The essay was published by the New York Times instead. Border Patrol shooting: Border Patrol shooting renews debate on use of force - Los Angeles Times The Mexican government and immigrant rights groups have condemned the shooting of a man trying to cross the border fence into the U.S. Tuesday evening near San Diego. Federal authorities say the man was throwing rocks at U.S. agents. Georgia immigrant crackdown backfires - Politico A state program to replace migrant farm workers, fleeing a tough new immigration law, with probationers backfired when some of the convicted criminals started walking off their jobs because field work was too strenuous, it was reported yesterday. Second part of California Dream Act advances - Multi-American The second of two state bills referred to as the “California Dream Act,” which would allow undocumented college students access to public financial aid for tuition, was approved by a state Senate committee yesterday.

item.title: In the news this morning: Undocumented journalist Vargas and deportation, Islamophobia on rise, TX governor's bad tequila joke, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Will Journalist Face Deportation? Signs Point To 'No' - NPR U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement's recent directives indicate that former Washington Post journalist Jose Antonio Vargas, who has revealed that he is undocumented, would not be a priority for deportation. Recent ICE memos have clarified the agency's focus on those who present "a clear risk to national security." Young Latinos Want Bicultural Content, Says Bilingual Channel - Fox News Latino Young Latinos ages 14 to 34 are eager for bilingual, bicultural content, says a study co-sponsored by Tr3s: MTV, Música y Más, a bilingual, bicultural channel. Jews, Muslims File Suit Against Proposed Circumcision Ban - Talking Points Memo A proposal in San Francisco to ban the circumcision of males under 18 is facing a legal challenge after opponents filed suit to block the measure from the ballot in November. UC Berkeley co-sponsored report finds Islamophobia on the rise - San Jose Mercury News Islamophobia is back on the rise in the U.S. despite cautious optimism in 2008 that post-Sept. 11 anti-Muslim sentiments had begun to decline, according to a report released today by the University of California at Berkeley and a national Islamic rights group. Illegal immigrant youth 'come out' in reform push - Associated Press The recent "coming out" of a prominent journalist comes on the heels of a broader youth movement, with undocumented youths revealing their immigration status as a political act. Rick Perry Tequila Joke Bombs Before Latino Audience - NPR Texas Gov. Rick Perry's joke at a meeting of the National Association of Latino Elected Officials, about how perfect it was to appoint Jose Cuevas to the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission - because his name sounds like Jose Cuervo - was not a hit.

item.title: In the news this morning: The Gold Cup final, 'coming out' undocumented, Latino ballplayers, state immigration laws, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded:
In Gold Cup final, it's red, white and boo again - Los Angeles Times A fan of Mexico's wildly supported national team, which beat the U.S. 4-2 at the Rose Bowl on Saturday, explains why the booing opposition: "We're not booing the country, we're booing the team," he said. An extraordinary tale that is all too ordinary - The Hill's Congress Blog On the "coming out" last week of ex-Washington Post journalist Jose Antonio Vargas as undocumented. Albert Pujols and the Plight of Latino Baseball Players - The Atlantic Many great Latino players may remain unsung, but there will be a wave of them eligible for the Hall of Fame over the next ten to 15 years. Alabama school board lacks policy for required immigration checks - Anniston Star Although it won’t go into effect until Sept. 1, a stringent Alabama state bill that would require schools to check for students' immigration status, among other things, is causing confusion among local school districts. Georgia immigration:  Many await the judge’s decision  - Atlanta Journal-Constitution A Georgia immigration law set to take effect Friday would empower local and state police to investigate the immigration status of certain suspects. But critics say the law is unconstitutional because it invites racial profiling.

Report: Feds downplayed ICE case dismissals - Houston Chronicle According to newly released records obtained through the Freedom of Information Act, Homeland Security officials tried to downplay immigration case dismissals in Houston and other cities amid accusations that they had created a "back-door amnesty."

item.title: In the news this morning: The Dream Act and the economy, state immigration laws, Latinas and health, lawsuit over wearing hijab at work, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Democrats pitch DREAM Act as needed economic patch - USA Today As Democrats renew their push for the Dream Act act in a Senate hearing this morning, the sales pitch will also focus on how the undocumented youths eligible for legalization under the bill can help the nation's foundering economy. Georgia, other states tackle immigration piecemeal - USA Today Five states this year followed Arizona's lead by passing laws that expanded the powers of local police officers to enforce immigration laws. South Carolina governor signs immigration bill into law - Reuters South Carolina's Republican Gov. Nikki Haley has signed into law a bill that requires police to check the immigration status of anyone they stop or arrest for another reason and suspect may be in the country illegally. Hispanic women are target of health efforts - Los Angeles Times Researchers want specifics on why 34.3 percent of Latino women in Illinois said their health was not good, compared with about 8.5 percent of non-Hispanic white women. Abercrombie & Fitch sued over hijab firing - San Francisco Chronicle A Bay Area Muslim woman, 20-year-old Hani Khan, sued Abercrombie & Fitch yesterday, claiming that the clothing retailer fired her when she refused to remove her religious headscarf while working at a San Mateo store.

item.title: In the news this morning: Dream Act hearing, immigration and demographics, opting out of Secure Communities, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Senate holds first hearing on DREAM Act - UPI Report on yesterday's first hearing on a new version of the federal immigration bill, in which key White House officials focused on economic and national security issues. The Nation: The Other Face Of Illegal Immigration - NPR On the admission last week by Pulitzer-winning journalist Jose Antonio Vargas that he is undocumented, and how it "complicates the usual terms of the immigration debate." America risks losing its immigration advantage - CNN Fareed Zakaria on immigration, economics, and the changing demographics of the United States, with immigration bolstering the country's young population growth. Feds: States Can't Keep Fingerprints To Themselves - NPR The federal government's reaction to states that seek to withdraw from the federal government's Secure Communities fingerprint-sharing immigration enforcement program. Immigration bill protesters granted signature bonds - Atlanta Journal-Constitution About 200 people, mostly students, rallied at the Georgia State Capitol yesterday against a new immigration bill set to take effect Friday. Three protesters arrested were later released on bond.

item.title: In the news this morning: Immigrant rights groups sue Sheriff Baca, Obama on E-Verify, Dream Act demonstrations, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Immigrants rights groups sue LA County sheriff Baca - 89.3 KPCC Immigrant advocacy groups are suing Los Angeles County Sheriff Lee Baca to force him to hand over information about the department's cooperation with federal immigration authorities, who operate Secure Communities and other programs in county jails aimed at identifying undocumented immigrants. President Obama Says E-Verify is an Effective Tool, but Needs to be Perfected - Fox News Latino In a press conference Wednesday, the president reiterated that he's committed to comprehensive immigration reform. He said that E-Verify, an online tool for screening workers' status that some legislators want to make mandatory, "can be an important enforcement tool if it's not riddled with errors." Hundreds of teachers recruited to NYC from Caribbean demand help with immigration status - The Washington Post Teachers recruited from Jamaica, Trinidad and other Caribbean countries ten years ago say that city officials have not made good on on promises to help them become citizens. They were recruited at a time when the city faced a teacher shortage. Weightlifting body changes dress code, benefits Muslim woman - CNN The International Weightlifting Federation has modified its rules, allowing athletes to wear full-body unitards during competition. The change was prompted by a female Muslim competitor from Atlanta, who wanted to dress modestly in accordance with her faith. Hundreds of students press Obama on DREAM Act - Fox News Latino Students who traveled to Washington, D.C. from as far as Texas, California and Florida demonstrated yesterday in favor of the Dream Act and a stop to deportations, first in an event in the Senate building and later in front of the White House.

item.title: In the news this morning: Georgia immigration law kicks in, same-sex partner's deportation stopped, the 'Irvine 11' case, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Tough Immigration Regulations In Effect In Georgia And South Carolina - Talking Points Memo A federal judge has temporarily blocked parts of a strict new Georgia new immigration law, but the rest goes into effect today, including one provision that would penalize people using a fake ID to get a job. South Carolina signed similarly strict legislation this week. Federal authorities drop deportation case against same-sex partner - CNN Federal authorities have halted the deportation of Venezuelan-born Henry Velandia, who came to the U.S. almost a decade ago and legally married his partner last year in Connecticut. Feds seek life sentence in border agent's death - The Associated Press Federal prosecutors seek life in prison for a Mexican man convicted of striking and killing a Border Patrol agent with a Hummer in the California desert in January 2008. The vehicle carried drugs; the agent was putting down spike strips in an attempt to puncture its tires. SF suit says circumcision ban is unconstitutional - San Francisco Chronicle A proposed ballot ban on circumcision in San Francisco would be "patently" unconstitutional, the city attorney's office said yesterday. An earlier lawsuit against the initiative was filed by Jewish and Muslim groups. Muslim students want charges dismissed - The Orange County Register A judge said yesterday that the case against 11 UC Irvine and UC Riverside students, accused of disrupting a speech by an Israeli diplomat early last year, will not be dismissed. A jury trial is scheduled to start in mid-August.

item.title: In the news this morning: Language clash over store signs, Georgia's new immigration law, rise in Latino UC students, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Sign of the times: Proposal to rewrite NYC store signs in English sparks culture clash - The Washington Post Two city council members are drafting legislation that would require store signs in in Flushing, Queens to be primarily in English. Mexico captures mastermind behind ICE agent slaying - Brownsville Herald Mexican authorities announced the arrest of Jesus Enrique "El Mamito" Rejón Aguilar, one of the top leaders in the Zetas drug cartel, who is accused in the death of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement Special Agent Jaime J. Zapata. The agent was shot to death in February on a Mexican highway. Immigration bill clarifies a once-muddy debate - Atlanta Journal-Constitution On how the passage of the state's stringent House Bill 87 has "brought a welcome clarity" to the illegal immigration debate in Georgia, illuminating how undocumented workers do work "most Georgians are unwilling or even unable to do." 2011 admissions reflect a changing UC in record high numbers of nonresident and Chicano/Latino students - Daily Bruin According to preliminary enrollment data released by the UC Office of the President, an expanding University of California undergraduate population will include historically high numbers of nonresident and Latino students. Record Number of Immigrants Becoming Citizens Through Military Service - KPBS More than 65,000 service members have become U.S. citizens since 2001, in part because of an increase in recruiting for the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. Ga. man key to crafting illegal immigration bill - The Associated Press The author of Georgia's strict new immigration law says that the assistance of longtime immigration restriction activist D.A. King "was invaluable in writing the law and organizing supporters to pressure lawmakers to pass it."

item.title: In the news this morning: Why migration from Mexico has slowed, Latinos and redistricting, Secure Communities, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: For Mexicans Looking North, a New Calculus Favors Home - New York Times Migration from Mexico has slowed to a trickle in recent years, in part due to growing economic and educational opportunities in Mexico, along with rising border crime and smaller families. Latinos Join the Electoral Land Grab - Wall Street Journal As electoral maps are redrawn, Latinos hope to boost their voting power. But many Latino groups are so far dissatisfied with redistricting plans in Texas, Illinois and California, which together will control nearly one-fourth of House of Representative seats after 2012. Georgia begins appeal after judge blocks parts of immigration law - CNN Attorneys representing the state of Georgia said the state is asking an appeals court to overturn a federal judge's decision that blocked several provisions of a stringent new state immigration law. Secure Communities Immigration Program A Gateway For Other FBI Data-Sharing - Huffington Post Documents released yesterday revealed more about the federal government's plans for the Secure Communities immigration enforcement program, and confirmed FBI plans to implement more security programs in which state participation would not be optional. Phoenix man gets 27 years in neighbor's death - Arizona Republic A white Phoenix man who shot his Latino neighbor to death in May 2010, as tensions flared over SB 1070, was sentenced Tuesday. Investigators said the shooter repeated a racial slur several times and told the victim to "go back to Mexico."

item.title: In the news this morning: Mexico migration changes, detention mistreatment allegations, a proposed immigration museum, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Immigration Upended: Damien Cave Answers Readers' Questions - New York Times The reporter who wrote a story on how economic and other improvements in Mexico are contributing to a slowdown in migration addresses questions from readers. DHS Investigates Complaints By Immigration Detainees - The Associated Homeland Security is investigating allegations that immigrant detainees have been mistreated at a detention facility in North Carolina. Teachers in middle of debate over immigrant kids - The Associated Press With an estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants in the U.S., educators often find themselves caught between their obligation to teach and conflicting guidance. Lawmakers want immigration museum in D.C. - The Washington Post Some members of Congress are calling for a presidential commission to study forming a National Museum of the American People in Washington to tell the history of immigration. Screening and Enforcement: A Snapshot of Federal Action on Immigration - Time On the forthcoming bill proposing a federal E-Verify law, state immigration measures and other aspects of the state of immigration policy and politics today.

item.title: In the news this morning: A flawed immigration court system, state bar considers undocumented lawyer, Mexican citizen executed in TX, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Removal of Priest’s Cases Exposes Deep Holes in Immigration Courts - New York Times The records of a priest with no formal legal training, who represented thousands of immigrants in New York's crowded federal immigration courts for decades, reveal the flaws in the immigration court system. Md. voters to decide immigrant tuition law - The Washington Post Opponents of a new Maryland law that would give undocumented immigrants access to in-state tuition at state public colleges have gathered enough signatures to suspend the law and to force a state referendum. Calif Bar weighs illegal immigrant's application - San Francisco Chronicle A California State Bar panel is considering whether Sergio Garcia, who passed the exam in 2009, should be admitted to practice law despite his status. Garcia was brought to the United States from Mexico as an infant. Mexican Citizen Is Executed as Justices Refuse to Step In - New York Times The Supreme Court turned down a request from the Obama administration yesterday evening that it stay the execution of Mexican citizen Humberto Leal Garcia Jr., convicted of murder and rape. He was executed in Texas about an hour later. Civil liberties groups could announce immigration suit today - The Times Daily Civil liberties groups in Alabama who have said they plan to sue to block a new state immigration law may announce plans today for a lawsuit.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
When Americans go to other countries, they are treated like crap. The are ripped off and always watched. They even have to keep their passport on them at all times. We are the land of the free over here and now too free. We have to crack down on illegals and drugs coming into this country. Mexico is the worst. Don’t get in trouble down there. You might not make it back to the states. People can come over here and make it, but an American would make it in their country.
Do you think other countries would have an American as a governor or some other important official? Heck no! An American would only get so far over there. We need to keep our rules strict and stop allowing everyone to become a U.S. citizen. Because you come over here just to have a kid so he or she can become a U.S. citizen is no reason to grant illegals citizenship. We have enough to deal with over here and don’t need any more. The United States is losing its edge!

item.title: In the news this morning: Major League Baseball and immigration, migrants stranded on Santa Cruz Island, D.C.'s dying Chinatown, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Arizona immigration law met by silence from Major League Baseball - USA Today Calls for the league to condemn Arizona's SB 1070 and take the All-Star game out of Arizona have gone unheeded. Groups are scheduled to protest outside Phoenix's Chase Field tomorrow. 15 suspected illegal immigrants found on Santa Cruz Island - Ventura County Star The U.S. Coast Guard and the National Park Service discovered a group of people stranded on the island yesterday who had apparently been left there since Friday by human smugglers. Wah Luck House maintains culture in dying D.C. Chinatown - The Washington Post On the last remaining residents of Washington, D.C.'s Chinatown, just 400 to 500 people, most of them elderly. Development and gentrification over the years has pushed most of the area's Chinese immigrant population into Maryland and Northern Virginia. Russell Pearce recall: Enough signatures to force election - Arizona Republic The architect of Arizona's controversial SB 1070, state Sen. Russell Pearce, appears certain to face what might be the first recall election of a state legislator in state history this fall. A recall effort has yielded enough valid signatures to force a special election. Mayor may pull Boston from immigration check plan - Boston Herald Boston mayor Thomas Menino has announced that he wants to withdraw Boston from the federal Secure Communities immigration enforcement program, which requires police to run criminal suspects’ fingerprints through an immigration database.

item.title: In the news this morning: Migrants rescued off Santa Cruz Island, wives of deportees bonding online, Mexico repatriation flights resume, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Illegal immigrants rescued off Santa Barbara coast - Los Angeles Times Fifteen Mexican citizens were stranded for days on Santa Cruz Island after being left there by smugglers. They used a cell phone to call for help. Tuscaloosa Hispanic population decreasing due to tornado, immigration law - Al.com There have been reports that some Latinos in Alabama are leaving the state following the approval of a new law that bans hiring of undocumented workers. Others left following a devastating tornado in late April. American-born wives married to U.S. deported or banned spouses band together via online networks - New York Daily News Blogger Giselle Stern Hernandez of "The Deportee's Wife" is one of a growing network of women bonding online after their husbands were deported or banned from reentering the U.S. U.S. and Mexico resume migrant repatriation flights - Reuters An annual voluntary repatriation program that flies Mexican nationals caught crossing illegally in the Arizona desert back to their homes in the Mexican interior resumed yesterday. The program has operated each summer since 2004. Immigrants May be Fed False Stories to Bolster Asylum Pleas - New York Times An underground industry dedicated to asylum fraud thrives in New York, where many of the country’s asylum claims are filed.

item.title: In the news this morning: More kids are children of immigrants, little protest at All-Star game in Arizona, smuggling by sea, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Census: Share of children in US hits record low - Associated Press Census numbers show that children now make up less of the nation's population than ever, even with a boost from immigrant families. Children of immigrants make up one in four people under 18. Plenty of Action Before the Game, but No Immigration Law Protests - New York Times The midsummer All-Star game at Chase Field in Phoenix did not draw significant protests over illegal immigration and Arizona's SB 1070. Many had called for protests and, at one point, a league boycott. Immigrant smuggling: Tightened borders force immigrant smugglers to take risky ocean routes - Los Angeles Times The trend of smuggling undocumented immigrants by sea, as well as drugs, up the California coastline continues to grow. Fifteen people were found stranded on Santa Cruz Island recently. States' immigration drive hits impasse in the courts - Reuters The stalemate in Arizona over SB 1070, still partially blocked as it works its way through the federal courts, is being echoed in other states with similar laws and legal challenges. Alabama Anti-Immigration Law the Bane of Farmers' Agricultural Existence - ABC News The civil rights attorneys and activists who have sued to block a newly approved Alabama immigration law say it would force farmers to replace undocumented migrant workers with employer-sponsored guest workers, "who would be relegated to a kind of indentured servitude."

item.title: In the news this morning: A deportation reprieve for same-sex couple, Muslim female weightlifter to compete, immigration audits, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Gay couple trying to avoid deportation given 2-year reprieve by San Francisco judge - San Francisco Examiner A federal judge in San Francisco has granted a two-year reprieve from deportation for a Venezuelan man to stay in the U.S. with his partner. Alex Benshimol, 47, overstayed a 10-year visitor visa. Ala. churches ready to fight immigration law - The Tennessean With Alabama recently passing what’s considered the nation’s most restrictive state immigration law, it's mainstream churches, faith-based organizations and their members who are leading the opposition. Abdullah breaking down barriers in weightlifting - USA Today Tomorrow, Kulsoom Abdullah will become the first woman to compete in the national weightlifting championships while wearing clothing that covers her arms, legs and head in keeping with Muslim religious standards of modest dress. Immigrant Recounts Experience in Detention Center - Fox News Latino Hector Rívera's story of five months spent in an Arizona immigrant detention facility is part of an American Civil Liberties Union report that denounces harsh conditions in detention centers. How a Small Business Can Survive an Immigration Audit - New York Times While the Bush administration carried out headline-making raids, the Obama administration has gone after employers, auditing their employment records on the theory that those who hire unauthorized workers create the demand responsible for driving most illegal immigration. Rep. Mo Brooks: I'll do "anything short of shooting" illegal immigrants  - CBS News An Alabama lawmaker is being criticized over comments he made last month regarding undocumented immigrants that included, "I will do anything short of shooting them."

item.title: In the news this morning: Latinos and population growth, a new green card lottery, Jose Antonio Vargas appears on Colbert Report, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Births, not immigration, account for most of Hispanic growth in last decade - CNN According to a new report from the Pew Hispanic Center, births have overtaken immigration as the force behind the growth of the Mexican American population in the U.S. over the last 10 years, and the Latino population overall. Plaintiffs Lose Fight Over Green-Card Lottery - Wall Street Journal A federal judge yesterday denied a request by plaintiffs who in May learned they had won a federal green card lottery, then learned the results would be scratched due to an error, not to hold another drawing. The State Department will throw out the old results and another drawing will be held. Gay couples in legal limbo with immigration - Los Angeles Times Married same-sex couples have learned that their marriages are not treated as other marriages when one of the partners is up for deportation, even if the Obama administration considers such deportation cases a low priority. Tough Alabama immigration law convinces some to move - Reuters Some undocumented immigrants are reportedly leaving the state as a new immigration law, described as the country's toughest illegal immigration crackdown, is set to take effect Sept. 1. Jose Antonio Vargas - The Colbert Report  - Video Clip An appearance on last night's Colbert Report show on Comedy Central by Jose Antonio Vargas, the former Washington Post journalist who last month admitted to having been in the country illegally since he was a minor.

item.title: In the news this morning: Jail for use of fake IDs to work in Georgia, Latina moms website launches, a 'Hispanic Tea Party' in Texas, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: New immigration law targets use of fake IDs - Atlanta Journal-Constitution A little known provision of Georgia's strict new immigration law that went into effect July 1 is called aggravated identity fraud, under which any adult who uses a fake ID to get work be imprisoned for 15 years and pay a steep fine. Latina Mothers a Rising Demographic—and Target of New Website, ‘Mamiverse’ - The Daily Beast A new website launches for Latina moms: "Mamiverse wants to be for Latinas what Oprah Winfrey was for African-Americans: a pal, a spiritual adviser, and, more subtly, an image-changer." Pharr pastor starts nation's first 'Hispanic Tea Party' - ValleyCentral.com Armando Vera, a Texas pastor and naturalized U.S. citizen, heads "the first-ever 'Hispanic Tea Party' in the United States." Family of U.S. agent slain in Mexico demands to know source of guns - Los Angeles Times The lawyer for the family of slain U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent Jaime Zapata, who was shot to death in Mexico, says U.S. officials refuse to answer questions about how the weapons used in his ambush were smuggled there. Does Georgia's immigration bill 'simply follow existing federal law?' - PolitiFact A statement fro a Georgia lawmaker that the state's new anti-illegal immigration law simply follows existing federal law receives a "half true" rating.

item.title: In the news this morning: Hate crime victim tries to save his attacker, GOP group seeks Latino candidates, Iraqi refugees under scrutiny, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: The Hater and the Hated, Both Touched by Crime - New York Times Q&As with Rais Bhuiyan, a Pakistani immigrant shot in the face after September 11, 2001, and with Mark Anthony Stroman, the man who shot him. Stroman, who killed two others, is on death row; Bhuiyan is circulating a petition to spare his life. RSLC unveils Latino recruitment plan - Politico The Republican State Leadership Committee has unveiled a new initiative intended to attract more Latino candidates to run for office as Republicans. BP steps up search for immigrants amid Texas heat - Houston Chronicle Excessive heat along the border has federal agents stepping up search and rescue efforts for migrants who may be overcome by the elements. Illegal immigrants matter, says 'Twilight' director - Home - The Orange County Register An interview with director Chris Weitz, who most recently directed "A Better Life," a film about an undocumented father in Los Angeles and his son. Iraqi refugees in U.S. rechecked for terrorism links - Los Angeles Times Federal authorities are rescreening more than 58,000 Iraqi refugees living in the United States following concerns about security lapses;  immigration officials have so far given the FBI about 300 names of refugees to investigate.

item.title: In the news this morning: Possible immigration overhaul bill, the undocumented population in CA, AZ seeks border fence donations, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Sen. Chuck Schumer tries reviving immigration bill - Politico The Democratic senator from New York says he plans to hold a hearing next week on economic arguments for an immigration overhaul. Arizona Officials, Fed Up with U.S. Efforts, Seek Donations to Build Border Fence - New York Times Arizona state legislators have created a state fund to take private donations to build more border fencing. They say it will allow "everyday people fed up with the inability of Congress to address the problem of illegal immigration" to contribute. Counting California's undocumented immigrants, by their tax returns - Multi-American A new report from the Public Policy Institute of California estimates Los Angeles County's undocumented population at a little less than one million. The count was based on public records by ZIP code for Individual Taxpayer Identification Numbers, used by people without work authorization. Chicago mayor creates support office for immigrants - Fox News Latino Mayor Rahm Emanuel has announced the creation of an Office of New Americans. The idea is to provide support for Chicago's immigrant communities and strengthen their ties to Chicago's economic, civic and cultural life. Martinez cracks down on driver's licenses - Alamogordo Daily News Susana Martinez said yesterday that she will require at least 10,000 foreign nationals to verify that they are New Mexico residents.

item.title: In the news this morning: Bill to end visa lottery goes to House, S.F.'s undocumented population, Georgia's immigration enforcement panel, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: House Judiciary Committee votes to send bill abolishing visa lottery program to full House - The Washington Post The House Judiciary Committee has approved a bill that would abolish the U.S. State Department’s visa lottery program. It next goes to the House floor for a vote. Majority of San Francisco's Illegal Immigrants Live in the Mission District - SF Weekly The results are from a new study released by the Public Policy Institute of California, which used public records from tax filings by ZIP code to come up with county and sub-county estimates of the state's undocumented population. New panel to punish officials who violate illegal immigration laws - Atlanta Journal-Constitution Three top lawmakers in Georgia are preparing to create an Immigration Enforcement Review Board, which would investigate state and local officials who fail to enforce the state's immigration laws. TLC orders All-American Muslim reality show - Entertainment Weekly TLC plans to debut a new series called "All-American Muslim." While not billed as a "Jersey Shore," the show does "follow the MTV hit’s trend of delving into a cultural community for reality entertainment," according to the story. Manhattan prints city user's guide for immigrants in Chinese and Spanish - New York Daily News The booklets and online guides will explain everything from how to start a small business to what to do if a family member is detained by immigration authorities. Patrick backs in-state college tuition for illegal immigrants - The Boston Globe Massachusetts governor Deval Patrick appeared before state legislators yesterday to urge them to let undocumented students pay reduced in-state tuition. Patrick has also come out against the controversial Secure Communities immigration enforcement program.

item.title: In the news this morning: Record deportations bolstered by traffic and DUI arrests, post-9/11 hate killer executed, in-state tuition, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Report: Deportations hit record number - Politico The Obama administration deported a record number of people last year, nearly 400,000. The number was driven up by the deportations of a large number of people arrested for traffic violations and drunken driving. "Arab Slayer" Executed After Victim Pleas for Clemency - KDAF In spite of pleas for clemency from one of his victims, Mark Anthony Stroman was executed in Texas by lethal injection. Stroman was convicted of killing two men he attacked after 9/11 because he believed them to be Arabs. Victim Rais Bhuyian, who circulated a petition to save him, survived being shot in the face. Immigration law: In Maryland, a fresh battle over state tuition - Los Angeles Times A new law allowing in-state college tuition for some undocumented students has been suspended until it can go to voters next year. Both sides have been mounting campaigns. Is East L.A. Ready To Be A City- LA Beez? A study was recently released that is key to determining whether unincorporated East Los Angeles has the resources to sustain itself as an independent city. Previous attempts at incorporating have failed. Groups seek to block tough Alabama immigration law - Reuters Civil rights groups have filed a motion in Alabama asking a federal judge to block what has been called the nation's most stringent new state immigration law.

item.title: In the news this morning: Obama courts Latinos, the Norway massacre and immigration, highly skilled immigrants, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Obama Steps Up Campaign To Win Over Latino Voters - NPR Today President Barack Obama will address the National Council of La Raza, the largest Latino advocacy group in the country. It's part of the White House's ongoing effort to win over Latino voters. Norway massacre exposes incendiary immigration issue - Reuters Anders Behring Breivik said that he killed 93 people in order to spark a "revolution" against "the multiculturalism he believed was sapping Europe's heritage." This Week in Tech: Lawmakers look at highly skilled immigrants - The Hill The Senate Judiciary Committee's subpanel on immigration will address the issue of highly skilled immigrants tomorrow at a hearing that will include representatives from the tech industry and academia. LA day laborers double as actors to teach, empower - Fox News The Day Laborer Theater Without Borders, composed of day labor and domestic workers, is a street theater troupe that performs at job centers. Their performances aim to teach immigrant laborers about their rights in the U.S. George Ramos, former L.A. Times editor, columnist, dies at 63 - Los Angeles Times Ramos was a respected mentor to younger Latino journalists. He played a key role in a Pulitzer-winning L.A. Times series on Latinos in Southern California in 1984, and later joined the journalism faculty at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo.

item.title: In the news this morning: Brown signs part of California Dream Act, Obama at NCLR conference, Norway immigration debate, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: California Dream Act: Brown expands education options for undocumented students - Los Angeles Times Gov. Jerry Brown signed a law yesterday allowing access to privately funded financial aid for undocumented college students, and signaled that he would likely back a more controversial proposal that could give these students access to public financial aid for tuition. Obama Tells Latino Voters He 'Needs a Dance Partner' on Immigration - ColorLines The president addressed immigration, education and the economy in a speech yesterday at the National Council of La Raza’s annual conference in Washington, D.C. Pioneer LA Chicano artist Gilbert 'Magu' Lujan dies at 70 - Southern California Public Radio "A typical Gilbert Lujan painting includes bright, chubby cars with lowrider paint jobs driven by Aztec warriors – or, sometimes, by dogs behind dark shades." Lujan, who died Sunday, had a career that spanned five decades. Strauss-Kahn's accuser: Schemer or immigrant survivor? - Reuters Opinions remain divided over the immigrant from Guinea who accused former IMF chief Dominique Strauss-Kahn of assaulting her in a New York hotel on May 14, where she worked as a maid. She has been portrayed as both virtuous and as a liar and schemer. Attack Reignites Immigration Debate in Divided Oslo - New York Times The deadly massacre in Norway by a suspect who wanted to start a "revolution" against changes brought by Muslim immigrants comes after Norway recently tightened its immigration and asylum rules, in light of a longstanding debate over assimilation and multiculturalism.

item.title: In the news this morning: Muslim hearings resume, wealth gap grows as minority wealth drops, Alabama immigration lawsuit, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Rep. Peter King Resuming Hearings On American Muslim Radicalization With Focus On Al-Shabab - CBS New York According to the New York Republican congressman, today’s hearing will focus on an organization he says has been recruiting American citizens of Somali descent in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area. Study: Housing Bust Hit U.S. Minority Households Especially Hard - PBS News Hour The economic divide between whites and other groups grew during the housing collapse and the recession: "Between 2005 and 2009, whites lost 16 percent of their median net worth, but Latinos lost 66 percent, black households 53 percent, and Asians, who had topped white households in 2005, dropped 54 percent." Immigrants Sue Alabama Over Immigration Law - Fox News Latino A new lawsuit filed in Alabama argues that a stringent new state immigration law will subject all immigrants to harassment; of the five plaintiffs, two are U.S. citizens who are immigrants from Mexico, two others are undocumented, and one is married to an undocumented immigrant Norway Atrocity May Not Dent Anti-Immigration - Bloomberg The public reaction to the massacre in Norway committed "in the name of combating 'Islamization'" may not be enough to curb the rise of anti-immigration parties across the region, according to experts. Rep. Luis Gutierrez Arrested Near White House in Dream Act and Immigration Protest - Fox News Latino The Illinois Democratic congressman was put in handcuffs Tuesday after protesting the Obama administration's deportation policies and his inability to push forward the DREAM Act, a proposal to grant conditional legal status to youths who go to college or join the military.

item.title: In the news this morning: Controversy over CA Supreme Court pick, a shift in Europe's immigration debate, the HALT Act, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: California Supreme Court nominee Goodwin Liu sparks criticism - Los Angeles Times Gov. Jerry Brown’s nominee, a UC Berkeley law professor, would join two other Asian American justices. There are no Latino or African American justices on the court following the retirement of Justice Carlos R. Moreno. Many had expected a Latino nominee. Former South Vietnam Premier Nguyen Cao Ky dies - Southern California Public Radio The former leader, who died in Malaysia, spent some time living in Orange County after the war. In 1984, an Orange County Register reporter discovered him running a liquor store there, in what he described as the county's "worst slum." Obama Takes Heat from Pro-Immigration Groups - Voice of America Hundreds of pro-immigrant activists gathered recently near the White House to protest what they consider President Obama's inaction on promised immigration reforms. “We are here to collect on the promises he made to us," one activist said. Shift in Europe Seen in Debate on Immigrants - New York Times The hate-driven massacre by that occurred less than a week ago in Norway seems to be prompting "a shift in the debate over Islam and the radical right in Europe" as shocked Europeans react to the crime. What is the HALT Act? - Multi-American A proposal heard in the House earlier this week aims to eliminate many long-employed forms relief for immigrants used on a case-by-case basis. The bill was introduced in reaction to a recent federal memo urging use of prosecutorial discretion in immigration cases. 'Queen of banda' inducted into Poly Walk of Fame - Southern California Public Radio Singer Jenni Rivera is known as the "Queen of Banda," that strain of Mexican music characterized by brass and percussion that derives from German cultural influences. She is a graduate of Long Beach Polytechnic High School.

item.title: In the news this morning: Killings test Norway's reputation as haven for immigrants, Latinos and the GOP, H-1B visas and U.S. workers, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Immigration, Integration Draw Attention In Norway - NPR The brutal attacks in Norway last week by Anders Behring Breivik have tested Norway's reputation as a welcoming haven for immigrants, many of them Muslims. ICE raid targets University of Northern Virginia - The Washington Post U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents raided the offices of the University of Northern Virginia yesterday, and have notified the school it may lose authorization to admit foreign students. The raid was part of an ongoing investigation, according to the agency. GOP Touts Latino Recruits, but Immigration Tension Remains - Time In a conference call earlier this week, Republican National Committee chairman Reince Priebus told reporters that the GOP is producing some of the country’s most promising Latino elected officials. But younger Latinos still tend to register as Democrats. For every H-1B visa, US technology companies hire 5 workers: NASDAQ - The Economic Times Refuting allegations that H-1B visas take away jobs from Americans, NASDAQ's chief is citing studies saying that for every H-1B visa holder hired, technology companies hire five workers. Hideki Irabu, former Yankees pitcher, found dead in Rancho Palos Verdes - Southern California Public Radio The former New York Yankees pitcher, who arrived in the U.S. in 1997, was billed as the "Japanese version of Nolan Ryan." He was found dead Wednesday, and authorities have pointed to suicide. He was 42.

item.title: In the news this morning: Redistricting and minorities, Illinois Dream Act, immigrant entrepreneurs, asylum difficulties, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Latest CA Redistricting Maps Satisfy Most Minorities, But Not Latinos - New America Media The California Citizens Redistricting Commission has approved new political boundaries, and civil rights groups are now weighing the impact the maps will have on communities of color. Immigrants' journey led to role as entrepreneurs - Minneapolis Star Tribune Immigrant resettlement, education and other services initially costs taxpayers some money, but the same immigrants soon become net economic contributors, according to researchers. Gov. Pat Quinn to Sign Illinois DREAM Act into Law - Fox News Latino The Illinois governor is getting ready to sign a bill that would give undocumented college students access to private scholarships, and allow them to enroll in state college savings programs. Farmers Oppose G.O.P. Bill on Immigration - New York Times Farmers are fighting a Republican-sponsored bill that would force employers to verify the legal immigration status of their workers. They say it could put future harvests at risk, as well as their support for conservative candidates. Minorities make huge housing gains - The Orange County Register Home ownership declined among non-Latino whites in the past decade, but the number of Latino and Asian homeowners grew significantly. Law inhibits many Mexican asylum cases - El Paso Times People fleeing drug-related violence or corrupt authorities in Mexico face difficulty when trying to obtain political asylum in the U.S. under the traditional legal interpretation of what constitutes persecution.

item.title: In the news this morning: DOJ sues over Alabama immigration law, in-state tuition controversy, Illinois Dream Act, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Justice Dept. challenges tough Ala immigration law - The Associated Press The Obama administration has sued Alabama over a stringent new state immigration law set to take effect Sept. 1, saying it conflicts with federal law and undermines the federal government's immigration priorities. Developers of Islamic Center Try a New Strategy - The New York Times A year after their plans were put off by controversy and protests, the developers of a Muslim community center and mosque in Lower Manhattan a few blocks from the site of the former World Trade Center are moving ahead, this time more slowly. Court to decide if immigrant tuition law goes to Maryland ballot - The Washington Post In a lawsuit filed yesterday, an immigrant rights group is charging that opponents of a new Maryland law that would give undocumented immigrants breaks on in-state college tuition have no right to force a referendum onto next year's ballot. Norco Family Accuses ICE Agents of Abuse - NBC Los Angeles During a news conference yesterday, a Norco family said federal agents raided the family's home in July looking for drug traffickers and drugs, and that they were kicked and beaten. They now go before immigration officials to plead their case to stay in the U.S. Quinn signs law providing private scholarships to undocumented immigrants - Chicago Tribune Illinois Gov. Pat Quinn signed a measure into law yesterday creating a privately funded scholarship program that would help documented and undocumented immigrants pay for college.

item.title: In the news this morning: Illegal re-entry tops list of federal charges, 18 years of Arpaio's 'tent city,' green cards for entrepreneurs, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Illegal re-entry topped all other charges in federal courts - Boston Herald Illegal re-entry was the most frequent federal criminal charge in the United States during the first six months of fiscal 2011. According to a report, federal prosecutors filed 18,552 illegal re-entry cases nationally between the start of the fiscal year last October and March. Sheriff Joe Arpaio's Tent City turns 18 - The Arizona Republic The Maricopa County sheriff's notorious compound of military-style tents has housed more than 500,000 people since it opened in the summer of 1993. Arpaio is to commemorate its 18th year with a "celebration" today. Ruling over Pa. town's immigration law vacated - Atlanta Journal-Constitution A federal appeals court has vacated a ruling that declared an illegal immigration law in the northeastern Pennsylvania city of Hazleton to be unconstitutional. The decision sets the stage for a new round of arguments. In Nordics, ethnic tensions beneath placid surface - The Associated Press Sweden, Denmark and Norway are known for efforts to build peaceful, egalitarian societies. But in spite of the attention paid to social harmony, there are roiling racial tensions. These have come to the forefront in light of the recent racially motivated mass killings in Oslo. Policy shift will help more immigrant entrepreneurs get green cards - New York Daily News The director of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services has announced a policy shift that will help more immigrant entrepreneurs qualify for green cards, particularly those with high-tech business aspirations.

item.title: In the news this morning: Bilingual parenting, minorities and the debt ceiling, backlash to a biracial Spider-Man, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Bloomberg to Use Own Funds in Plan to Aid Minority Youth - The New York Times The New York mayor has announced plans to spend nearly $130 million on measures to improve the circumstances of young black and Latino men who are "cut off from New York’s civic, educational and economic life." To raise bilingual children, some families try "one parent, one language" approach - The Washington Post Parents are trying different approaches as the number of bilingual households grows. According to the 1980 Census, only 11 percent of  Americans lived in homes where languages other than English were spoken. As of 2007, that percentage had nearly doubled. White House unveils plan to combat domestic militancy - Reuters The Obama administration, citing concerns about al Qaeda militants trying to recruit Muslim in the U.S., has unveiled a unveiled a strategy that involves reaching out to local communities. In California farming town a Latino congregation commits to Judaism - The Jewish Chronicle A feature on the Congregación Beth Shalom, a congregation of Jewish Latinos in agricultural Santa Maria, California. Will the Debt Ceiling Deal Adversely Affect Latinos? - Fox News Latino Rep. Charles Rangel of New York, who represents an increasingly Latino population in Harlem, believes that Latino and black Americans will suffer most under a debt deal that includes heavy cuts to social programs. Backlash To Black-Latino Spiderman Indicates We're Not A Post-Racial Society - Atlanta Post On the backlash to the introduction of Miles Morales, the new Spiderman character who is a "half-black, half-Hispanic" teenager.

item.title: In the news this morning: NY minority youth plan draws fire, 16 countries oppose AL immigration law, new detention center debated, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: NYC program for young men draws praise, questions - The Wall Street Journal Mayor Michael Bloomberg's announcement of a $127 million project that aims to help about 315,000 black and Latino men between ages 16 and 24 is meeting with both praise and criticism. Pr. William officials file lawsuit against DHS - Virginia Politics - The Washington Post Virginia's Prince William County has filed a lawsuit against the Homeland Security department, demanding information on the undocumented immigrants that the county has transferred to DHS. 16 Countries, Including Mexico, File Briefs Against New Alabama Immigration Law - Fox News Sixteen countries have filed briefs against Alabama's controversial new immigration law, which is already being challenged by the federal government. The Birmingham attorney who filed the brief told media that the nations protesting  “want to have one immigration law and not 50.” South Fla town debates plan for detention center - The Miami Herald Residents and immigrant activists in South Florida's Broward County are debating a proposed plan to place one of the nation's largest immigration detention centers in an upscale rural area nearby. The planned 2,000 bed facility would be operated by Corrections Corporation of America, the largest private prison company in the U.S.

item.title: In the news this morning: Secure Communities to go on without states' approval, a deportee returns, slavery allegations in NY, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Immigration authority terminates Secure Communities agreements - The Washington Post U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement director John Morton sent a letter to state governors Friday terminating the state agreements with the federal government “to avoid further confusion.” The controversial program is to continue without states' approval. Flight from Mexico: Students enroll in El Paso schools, immerse themselves in learning English - El Paso Times Schools in El Paso have become a refuge for Mexican students and their families who have fled across the border, trying to escape the drug war violence in Juarez. Latin Artists Band Together to Sue Grammys - Latina Several prominent Latino musicians are suing the Grammy Awards. The lawsuit surrounds the cutting of 31 awards categories recently by the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences. Among these categories were Latin jazz, salsa and traditional blues. Happy Ending for a Chicago Family Separated by the U.S. Immigration System - New York Times In what's a very rare case, a Polish woman will be returning home to Chicago on Monday afternoon with a legal immigrant visa, coming back to the United States after her deportation four years ago. In Suit, Housekeeper Says Buddhist Monk Enslaved Her in His Queens Home - The New York Times A Korean immigrant who worked as a housekeeper has accused her former employer, a Buddhist monk and his family, of enslaving her for 12 years and forcing her to work under death threats. Muslim woman says head scarf spurred threat in Ann Arbor - The Detroit News The 21-year-old woman says she was accosted by another motorist at an intersection in Ann Arbor, Michigan. She said the man hurled insults like "You don't belong here" and "You are a terrorist," and appeared to point a handgun at her.

item.title: In the news this morning: Deported woman returns, Secure Communities decision criticized, immigrant entrepreneurs, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Polish family reunited at O'Hare - WGN-TV Chicago Four years after her deportation to Poland and after a lengthy appeal, Janina Wasilewski has returned to the United States with her young son to join her husband in Chicago. Their case is a very rare one. S.F. gay married couple loses immigration battle - San Francisco Chronicle At the same time, bad news for another couple: The Obama administration has denied immigration benefits to a married gay couple, ordering the deportation of a man who is primary caregiver to his AIDS-afflicted spouse. Federal immigration-check requirement draws ire - USA Today Civil rights groups are contemplating a lawsuit over the federal government's decision to rescind contracts and force states to comply with Secure Communities, a fingerprint-sharing immigration enforcement program opposed by some state and local governments. Paving the Way for More Immigrant Entrepreneurs - Entrepreneur Last week, U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services announced a policy shift that aims to help more immigrant entrepreneurs start up businesses in the U.S. through what's called an "employment-based second preference immigrant visa." Ramirez taking high road regarding Tony Bruno's tweets - Sporting News Dominican-born San Francisco Giants pitcher Ramon Ramirez says he's not ruffled over a sports talk radio host, Tony Bruno, recently calling him an "illegal alien" on Twitter after the Giants and the Philadelphia Phillies were involved in a brawl. Mexico says immigration outflow drops to "almost nothing" - The Washington Post A report based on quarterly surveys by Mexico's National Statistics Institute says the country lost about 0.09 percent of its population to migration between March 2010 and March 2011. That is 83 percent lower than the outflow in 2006 and early 2007, near the end of Mexico’s migration boom.

item.title: In the news this morning: Latinos and L.A. County redistricting, immigration checks, Secure Communities in California, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Board of Supervisors weighs idea of new Latino-majority district - Los Angeles Times Latino activists want for the county to create a second Latino-majority voter district. They say that demographic shifts in the last decade demand it, with Latinos now making up 48 percent of the county's population. Immigrants face checks on way back to Mexico - Sacramento Bee It's not unusual to see federal agents conducting outbound inspections, checking buses and other vehicles as people exit the United States into Mexico at the border. Feds circumvent state on immigration fingerprint checks - California Watch If a decision from ICE last week to rescind state contracts on Secure Communities holds up, forcing states to comply, a California bill that would allow the state to opt out of the controversial enforcement program could be irrelevant. Ariz. governor on deadline for immigration appeal - The Associated Press Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona faces a deadline today for asking the U.S. Supreme Court to accept her appeal of a ruling that put on hold key parts of SB 1070 last year. Russell Pearce, father of Arizona immigration law, now facing recall - Christian Science Monitor The conservative Arizona state legislator who championed SB 1070 faces a Nov. 8 recall election, and some members of his own party say his agenda has gone to far.

item.title: In the news this morning: Arizona appeals Supreme Court on SB 1070, Whole Foods' Ramadan marketing controversy, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Ariz. governor files appeal with over immigration law - USA Today Attorneys for Arizona governor Jan Brewer filed a long-awaited petition with the U.S. Supreme Court yesterday over SB 1070, asking the court to overturn a lower court's injunction last year blocking portions of the state immigration law. At Ramadan Dinner, Obama Honors Muslim Americans Lost on 9/11 - ABC News At an Iftar dinner at the White House celebrating the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, President Obama spoke about the upcoming 10-year anniversary of the September 2001 attacks. “We must be the America that goes forward as one family,” he said. Children Of Immigrants Face Hardship To Keep Families Together - Huffington Post Parents being deported face a difficult choice, having to decide whether to take their children with them and force them to leave home, or leave them in the United States with another parent or family member. Whole Foods Draws Controversy Over Ramadan Promotion - Time Backlash from far-right critics has Whole Foods going back and forth on its promotion of halal food items for Ramadan, the Islamic holy month. Hispanic Organizations Give Obama and Congress a C - New York Times In a progress report on priority issues, leaders of the nation’s largest Latino organizations are giving the Obama administration only a passing grade. At issue in particular is a lack of movement on desired immigration reforms.

item.title: In the news this morning: Young students dropping out, anti-Latino hate crimes on the rise, the Asian American experience in portraits, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: California reports eighth-grade dropout rate for first time - Los Angeles Times About 3.5% of California eighth-graders, or 17,257 students, left school and didn't return for ninth grade. Gaps persist between ethnic groups, with the high school graduation rate at 68 percent for Latinos and 59 for African American students. Review: 'What is an Asian American?' at the National Portrait Gallery - The Washington Post A new exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery aims to depict the Asian American experience and identity in photographs, charcoal sketches, video and painting. US chided for slow reveal of immigration program - Seattle Post-Intelligencer A federal judge in New York ordered lawyers yesterday for an update on progress made toward disclosing documents about U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement's Secure Communities immigration enforcement program to civil rights groups. Report: Anti-Latino hate crimes surge - Riverside Press-Enterprise The number of anti-Latino hate crimes surged statewide last year, according to a report from the state attorney general's office. The report noted 119 anti-Latino crimes in California in 2010, up nearly 50 percent from the 81 in 2009. There was also a slight rise in the overall number of hate crimes statewide. Governor's Great Grandparents Were Illegal Immigrants - KOAT Albuquerque New Mexico Gov. Susana Martinez, who supports a controversial bill that would bar undocumented immigrants from obtaining driver's licenses, "said she has something in common with the protesters because her own ancestors came to the country illegally, but it will not affect her position." She says the bill addresses public safety.

item.title: In the news this morning: 'Immigration detainer' lawsuit, redistricting, immigrant detention, unauthorized workers go underground, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Homeland Security sued over immigrant detention - Los Angeles Times A Chicago civil rights group has filed a class-action lawsuit in federal court against Homeland Security, alleging that the agency's practice of having local police detain immigrants for immigration authorities - what's referred to as an "immigration detainer" - without evidence of a crime is unconstitutional. Undocumented immigrants face checks on Amtrak, Greyhound - Miami Herald Federal agents appear to have stepped up inspections for undocumented immigrants on public transportation, including Greyhound buses and Amtrak. The federal government says agents have the authority to conduct inspections in public places. Calif. Redistricting Likely To Have National Impact - NPR Part of what's determining how the political boundaries are redrawn is the continued growth of the state's Latino population, outside of the urban areas and into rural and suburban areas. Jailing Undocumented Immigrants Is Big Business (VIDEO) - Huffington Post Homeland Security pays a steep per diem fee per person to contracted local, county and state prison facilities (as well as private contract detention centers) to house apprehended immigrants. Immigration Audits Drive Illegal Workers Underground - Wall Street Journal Audits of businesses by the federal government have forced employers to let go of unauthorized workers, driving some of these workers deeper underground. Judge OKs Recall Election Against Author Of AZ Immigration Law - Talking Points Memo An Arizona judge has approved a November election for the recall of state Sen. Russell Pearce (R), the legislator behind the controversial SB 1070 immigration law.

item.title: In the news this morning: Secure Communities hearing, 'The Submission,' CA redistricting and Latinos, missing migrants, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Task force hears concerns, complaints about Secure Communities deportation program - Southern California Public Radio In a packed town hall meeting last night in Los Angeles, hundreds of people opposed to Homeland Security's Secure Communities immigration enforcement program voiced their complaints to a federal task force, saying it undermines trust in local police. Frequent flier fracas: Muslims face travel woes - San Francisco Chronicle A Muslim civil rights group has sent letters to federal officials on behalf of two young Muslim men, saying they were improperly placed on a no-fly list. The two have been unable to board international flights. The Submission by Amy Waldman: Book Review - USA Today "What if a Muslim-American architect won an anonymous competition to design a memorial at Ground Zero for the victims of 9/11? Should an architect's religion trump his design?" These are among the questions posed by Amy Waldman's much talked about new novel, "The Submission." California's New Election Map Draws Fire from GOP and Latino Groups - Fox News Latino An independent redistricting commission has given its final approval to a new California election map that redraws the state's political boundaries. Critics of the map say it benefits Democrats but doesn't fairly represent the state's Latino population. Illegal immigrant who oversaw abuse at 'drop house' gets 20 years - Los Angeles Times A 29-year-old Guatemalan man who directed a "drop house," where immigrants were held against their will and say they were tortured with cattle prods and other devices, was sentenced yesterday. The Other Border: Families Look for Missing Migrants in Mexico - Huffington Post Families of migrants from Central American countries have traveled by caravan to Mexico City, seeking answers as to what happened to their loved ones en route to the United States.

item.title: In the news this morning: Redistricting complaints, border deaths, church opposition to Alabama immigration law, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Fallout from Republicans, Latinos over state redistricting maps - Southern California Public Radio California's redrawn political boundaries don't sit well with GOP leaders who say they give Democrats an edge, or with Latino groups, who say Latino voters won't be adequately represented. Ariz. border immigrant deaths drop 38 pct - UPI The Border Patrol's Tucson sector has reported 132 migrant deaths for the 10 months ending July 31, down from 212 a year earlier during the same period. Alabama immigration law un-Christian, say church leaders - Public Radio International A stringent new state immigration law has already been opposed by farmers and contractors, and church leaders are now expressing their opposition. A group of 150 Alabama church leaders has signed an open letter saying they intend to break the law. Obama slammed on immigration - Boston Herald Latino immigrant advocates say the president is alienating Latino voters with his tough immigration stance, with one saying it could "possibly lose him the election” in 2012. Federal Policy Resulting in Wave of Deportations Draws Protests - The New York Times The federal government's Secure Communities immigration enforcement program has drawn protests in six cities over the last two days, including during a Department of Homeland Security town hall meeting in Los Angeles on Monday.

item.title: In the news this morning: Redistricting in L.A., immigrant taxi dancers suing club, border shooting lawsuit dismissed, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Yaroslavsky's Westside district would be carved up by Latino plan - Los Angeles Times L.A. County supervisor Gloria Molina has proposed a redistricting plan that would create a second Latino seat on the county Board of Supervisors. Farm workers entitled to nearly $2 million - The Associated Press A federal appeals court has awarded nearly $2 million to more than 600 Latino farm workers in Washington state, who accused a labor contractor and two state growers of violating federal labor laws. Taxi dancers suing nightclub owners who cater to Latino immigrants - Southern California Public Radio Former taxi-dancers who worked at Club 907 in Los Angeles say they didn't even earn minimum wage. They have filed a class-action lawsuit against the owners of the club, which was raided by police last year. Colleges ask proof of legal residency - Atlanta Journal-Constitution Students admitted to Georgia's five most competitive public colleges are for the first time being asked to prove they are in the U.S. legally before enrolling in fall semester classes. So far, only one student has been barred due to immigration status. Suit dismissed in shooting death of Juárez boy by Border Patrol agent - El Paso Times A judge has dismissed a $25 million lawsuit against the United States filed by the family of a 15-year-old Juárez boy shot and killed by a Border Patrol agent on the Rio Grande last year. Because he was shot on the Mexican side, the U.S. government can't be sued, the ruling concludes.

item.title: In the news this morning: Repatriation flights criticized, some same-sex couples' deportations halted, an immigration protest with curry, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Repatriation flights for illegal immigrants draw criticism - USA Today Homeland Security has spent more than $85 million in past eight years to fly Mexican migrants caught crossing through Arizona back to the interior, away from the border. The aim is to deter them from trying again, but there's "no real way to gauge the value of the program." Some Deportations Halted for Gay Immigrants - The Advocate The Obama administration’s news last week that it would make certain deportations a low priority has been good news for some binational same-sex couples, including one married couple in Denver. Singaporeans' culinary anti-immigration protest: curry - Reuters "Tens of thousands of people in the Southeast Asian city-state said they would cook or eat curry on Sunday in a protest highlighting growing anger over increased immigration." Really. Illegal Alien Who Saved Child Is in Center of Debate on New Policy for Illegal Immigrants - ABC News Last week, Antonio Diaz  Chacon jumped into his pickup truck and pursued the alleged abductor of a 6-year-old girl, who crashed into a light pole in Albuquerque, N.M. and was arrested. Then while he was being interviewed by reporters, Chacon revealed his immigration status. Border Sheriffs Seek Donations to Unblock Arizona Immigration Law - Fox News Latino A group of law enforcement officials representing Cochise County on Arizona's border with Mexico is seeking $60,000 in donations to file a brief with the U.S. Supreme Court in support of SB 1070. U.S. probes alleged bias by sheriff in public housing inspections - Los Angeles Times The U.S. Justice Department is to investigate alleged discrimination by L.A. County sheriff’s deputies in the Antelope Valley, involving potential civil rights violations against mostly black and Latino residents of subsidized housing.

item.title: In the news this morning: Changes underway from new deportation policy, Alabama in court over immigration law, entrepreneur visas, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Advocates cheer new immigration rules but expect Obama to follow through - The Hill Immigrant advocates say that President Obama's move to review and halt the deportations of thousands will resonate with Latino voters only if he backs it up. Battle over Alabama immigration law heads to court Wednesday - al.com Another court date is set for tomorrow in the U.S. Justice Department lawsuit against Alabama over the state's new immigration law, which the Justice Department has called "non-cooperative." Advocates Urge Easier Visa Policies To Boost Startups - NPR In an effort to attract more high-skilled foreign entrepreneurs, the White House recently announced more flexible policies for granting visas. But some experts say the planned changes aren't enough. Obama's deportation focus shifts from gay families - San Francisco Chronicle The Obama administration has halted its attempt to deport a member of a same-sex California couple who overstayed his visa, reflecting a shift in the administration's deportation policy. U.S. Issues New Deportation Policy's First Reprieves - New York Times Manuel Guerra, an undocumented immigrant from Mexico living in Florida who has been fighting deportation for five years, is among the first to be informed that he won't be deported under new guidelines.

item.title: In the news this morning: NYPD targets Muslim communities, a 'graduation' protest, Alabama immigration law in court, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: With CIA help, NYPD moves covertly in Muslim areas - The Associated Press An investigation by The Associated Press has found that the New York Police Department "operates far outside its borders and targets ethnic communities in ways that would run afoul of civil liberties rules if practiced by the federal government." License Access in New Mexico is Heated Issue - New York Times New Mexico is one of just two states that allow residents who are undocumented to get the same driver’s licenses given to citizens. Among the policy's opponents who want to change this is newly elected Gov. Susana Martinez. In Georgia, a 'graduation' to protest illegal immigrant ban - Los Angeles Times A mock graduation ceremony was held to protest a recently implemented state policy banning undocumented immigrants from Georgia's top five public colleges and universities. Perry's immigration stances draw fire, support - Houston Chronicle Critics have challenged the changing immigration politics of Texas Gov. Rick Perry, who on the verge of a presidential run. Alabama at Center of National Debate Over Immigration - Wall Street Journal There is a hearing today in Alabama federal court over the state’s new immigration law, considered one of the strictest in the country, which is being challenged by the federal government.

item.title: In the news this morning: Undocumented hero stirs controversy, New Mexico license lawsuit, arrests at LA immigration protest, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Is New Mexico illegal immigrant a hero or a criminal? - Los Angeles Times Antonio Diaz Chacon of Albuquerque has been honored after his heroic rescue of a 6-year-old girl from a suspected kidnapper. But he is also undocumented. His story has "set off a firestorm in a state warring over how best to handle undocumented residents." New Mexico sued over residency verification for licenses - Fox News The Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund has filed a lawsuit in federal court to stop a program that would verify the residency of 10,000 allegedly undocumented immigrants who obtained New Mexico driver's licenses. On Immigration, Will Rick Perry Throw the Tea Party Under the Bus? - Mother Jones More on Texas governor and presidential hopeful Rick Perry's complicated stance on immigration as he tries to appeal to a GOP base that is divided between business and enforcement. The Alabama Town Most Changed (and Saved) by Immigration - ColorLines "From a distance—the perspective from which immigration is too often discussed—Russellville can seem like an apt illustration of why Alabama should crack down on immigrants." An Alabama small-town case study. 7 arrested at downtown L.A. pro-immigration protest - Los Angeles Times Police arrested at least seven people during a protest outside the Ronald Reagan Federal Building downtown, where demonstrators blocked a driveway to prevent the departure of buses loaded with immigrants to be deported.

item.title: In the news this morning: California Dream Act, changes seen from new deportation policy, Latinos are largest minority on campus, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: California Senate panel OKs part of Dream Act - Los Angeles Times A state bill that would give college students who are undocumented access to public aid for the first time has moved out of committee and been cleared for a Senate vote. First Deportation Cases To Benefit From New Immigration Policy - Huffington Post Two young men in Georgia are among the first apparent beneficiaries of a new Obama administration policy aimed at making undocumented immigrants with no criminal record a low deportation priority. Alabama Immigration Law Faces Challenge In Court - NPR Alabama's controversial immigration law, said to be the strictest such state law in the country, is set to take effect in September. It is being challenged in court by the U.S. Justice Department, civil rights groups and religious leaders. Latinos largest minority on college campuses - Southern California Public Radio A new study shows that for the first time, young Latinos are the largest minority group on college campuses in the U.S., the result of a surge in Latino enrollment. The African American college student population grew only slightly. EPA settles civil rights complaint over pesticide - Forbes The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has settled a 1999 civil rights complaint, finding that California pesticide regulators discriminated against Latino schoolchildren when they approved the use of methyl bromide near their schools.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: While I do not support this act because it provides an incentive for illegal behavior, I do believe the alternative will cost taxpayers more in the long run; crime & punishment cost much more than education.

item.title: In the news this morning: Deportation reviews, Secure Communities, Perry bills feds for incarcerated immigrants, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Deportation reviews raise some immigrants' hopes - Los Angeles Times Immigrant advocates are urging caution as the Obama administration plans to review nearly 300,000 deportation cases and terminate those considered a low priority. Perry bills feds $349M for illegal immigrants - The Associated Press Texas governor and presidential hopeful Rick Perry has asked Homeland Security for nearly $350 million to cover costs he says Texas has incurred incarcerating undocumented state and county inmates. Bay Area forum condemns Secure Communities immigration program - Los Angeles Times More than 200 attended a public meeting this weekend, criticizing the immigration enforcement program that was "intended to target 'serious convicted criminals'" but that is also landing people with minor or no offenses in deportation.
