Barack Obama's uncle has been arrested and held as illegal immigrant - The Australian The arrest of Onyango Obama, a long-lost uncle of the president, "ends a mystery over the fate of a relative that the US President wrote in his memoir had moved to America from Kenya in the 1960s." He was allegedly held for driving under the influence. Hundreds Protest Illegal Immigration Law at Alabama Capitol Steps - WAKA CBS 8 News Hundreds protested this weekend against Alabama's new illegal immigration law, which will go into effect in just four days. Considered the nation's strictest, it is being challenged in federal court. Mexican soap opera takes close look at 9/11 - El Paso Times The telenovela "The Eighth Commandment," portrays fictionalized scenes from the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks on both sides of the U.S.-Mexico border.

item.title: In the news this morning: A survey of American Muslims, Alabama immigration law blocked, Obama's uncle held by ICE, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Survey: Muslim-Americans happier with conditions in US than broader public - Christian Science Monitor According to a new Pew Research Center report, "for the most part, Muslim-Americans disavow Islamic extremism, are happy with the way things are going in the country and in their lives, and are about as religious and educated as the general American public." Judge temporarily blocks tough Alabama immigration law - CNN A federal judge has temporarily blocked enforcement of a tough immigration law in Alabama that was schedueld to take effect Thursday. Opposition to the measure includes church leaders, the U.S. Justice Department and the American Civil Liberties Union. For Bay Area immigrants facing imminent deportation, new Obama policy offers no reprieve - San Jose Mercury News Arturo Rengifo Jr., a Peruvian-born college student who has lived in the United States since he was 6, is one of many immigrants "caught in a bureaucratic tangle: While the administration has announced its intent to change immigration policy, it hasn't yet implemented a new system, so planned deportations are proceeding." Casino Town Puts its Money on Hispanic Market - New York Times Primm Valley Casino Resorts outside Las Vegas, on the California-Nevada border, is aggressively courting Latino consumers with bilingual dealers and rules printed in Spanish on blackjack tables. Obama uncle held in US by immigration officials - The Associated Press Onyango Obama, 67, was arrested last week in Framingham, Massachusetts, near Boston, on suspicion of drunk driving. Born in Kenya, he is the half-brother of the president's late father. He was being held without bail on a detainer from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

item.title: In the news this morning: GOP candidates court Latinos, Obama's uncle called immigration 'fugitive,' global migration, foreign students, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: As Perry ascends, Romney chases Latino vote - Los Angeles Times Latinos have not previously been a big factor in Republican nomination races, but they could be next winter. Mitt Romney plans to address the Republican National Hispanic Assembly convention later this week in in Florida. Surge in Global Migration Expands Scale of an Aid Group's Influence - New York Times As global migration has expanded, so has the influence of a group called the International Organization for Migration, "a little-known group whose eclectic work shapes migrants’ lives across six continents." Obama's uncle called a fugitive from deportation since 1992 - The Boston Globe Federal officials speaking on condition of anonymity have said that Onyango Obama, 67, had been ordered to leave the country in 1992 did not go. The president's long-lost uncle was arrested on suspicion of drunk driving last week and is being held by immigration authorities. Gutierrez praises new Obama deportation policy, warns against predators - Chicago Sun-Times In the wake of the Obama administration's announcement that it will review deportation cases, Illinois Democratic Rep. Luis Gutierrez is warning Chicago’s immigrant communities not to fall prey to scam artists who might offer to sign them up for legalization. Foreign Student Workers Allege Exploitation - New America Media (via La Opinión) Students on work visas through a U.S. State Department summer program complain of "exhausting workdays, overcrowding, and debt."

item.title: In the news this morning: Outrage over anti-Muslim coloring book, CA Dream Act approved in Senate, Obama's uncle, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: 9/11 Coloring Book Sparks Outrage From Muslim Group - TIME A children's coloring book called "We Shall Never Forget 9/11: The Kids' Book of Freedom" uses terms like "freedom-hating radical Islamic Muslim extremists." Its publisher insists the intent of the book is to "educate, not offend." State Senate OKs part of California Dream Act - Los Angeles Times The state Senate approved 22-11 a bill that would give undocumented college students access to public financial aid, part of a two-bill package that makes it easier for these students to pay tuition. It now goes to back to the Assembly. Plan to Verify Immigrant Licenses in New Mexico is Put on Hold by Judge - Fox News Latino A judge has blocked a law that would require tens of thousands of immigrants to re-certify their driver's licenses and verify their state residency. Republican New Mexico Gov. Susana Martinez has been a vocal supporter. Obama's uncle set to fight deportation - The Boston Globe Onyango Obama has gone to the same law firm that helped his younger sister, Zeituni Onyango, overturn a deportation order and win asylum last year. The 67-year-old half-brother of the president's late father has lived in the U.S. almost 50 years. Texas jury considers case of helicopter pilot accused of lying about Mexican's drowning - The Washington Post A jury is deciding the fate of a Homeland Security pilot who is accused of lying about hovering his helicopter over two men attempting to cross the Rio Grande before one of them drowned.

item.title: In the news this morning: Prolonged immigrant detention ruled unconstitutional, CA Dream Act goes to Assembly, Katt Williams apology, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Years-long immigrant detentions unconstitutional, appeals court rules - CNN A federal appeals court has ruled that the "prolonged imprisonment of immigrants fighting deportation -- without giving them bail hearings and without forcing the government to justify the detention -- is unconstitutional." Illegal immigration is flash point for Republican White House hopefuls - The Washington Post The candidates are bringing up other issues such as the economy, but their GOP constituents, even those far from the border, continue responding to immigration issues. Treat uncle's deportation case like any other, Obama says - The Boston Globe A White House press secretary has said that "President Obama expects his uncle’s deportation case to be treated like any other immigration matter." His 67-year-old half-uncle Onyango Obama is being held for allegedly violating a 1992 deportation order. Dream Act: California embraces anti-Arizona role on illegal immigration - Christian Science Monitor A bill that would grant public financial aid for tuition to undocumented college students is on its way to the state Assembly for approval. Muslim Leaders Criticize Police Response to Scuffle - New York Times Muslim civil rights leaders have accused authorities of using excessive force after an amusement park’s restrictions on hijab, women's religious head coverings, provoked an altercation that led to 15 arrests. Activist accepts Katt Williams' apology for anti-Mexican rant - CNN The comic has issued a written statement through his publicist that includes an apology for a rant at a Phoenix nightclub, which escalated after he told a club patron to go back to Mexico.

item.title: In the news this morning: NYPD collected data on mosques, Latino leaders worried about 2012 races, 'undocumented' vs. 'illegal,' more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Docs: NYPD eyed 250-plus mosques, student groups - Associated Press According to officials and internal documents, the New York Police Department collected intelligence on more than 250 mosques and Muslim student groups in the New York area, often with the aid of informants. Latino leaders not optimistic about 2012 races - The Washington Post Latino political leaders fear that in spite of more than a dozen new districts created by redistricting - districts in which Latinos could constitute a majority - it's doubtful they can be won by Latino candidates. EB-5 visa program lets immigrants buy their way into U.S. - Los Angeles Times The federal EB-5 visa program is relatively small, limited to wealthy foreigners who can afford to invest $500,000 in a business that creates jobs, and is capped at 10,000 annual visas. But applications have skyrocketed since 2006. The Times' style: 'Illegal immigrant' or 'undocumented immigrant,' not 'illegal alien' - Los Angeles Times In a second piece on this issue in a week spurred by readers, the newspaper states its position on the debate, saying that its style is to use "illegal" or "undocumented" immigrant, but not "illegal alien." New Mexico to mull changes to immigrant driver's licenses - CNN New Mexico legislators plan to take up the debate today over proposed changes that would bar undocumented immigrants from obtaining state driver's licenses, and require thorough checks for applicants.

item.title: In the news this morning: Latinos and LA County political boundaries, 'Irvine 11' trial begins, no relief for would-be child immigrants, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Foes sound off in L.A. County supervisorial district fight - Los Angeles Times More than 800 people packed a Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors meeting yesterday for "a tense five-hour exchange of starkly different visions of how political boundaries should be redrawn in light of the region's steadily increasing Latino population." Appeals court rejects case filed by immigrants vying to bring now-adult children to US - The Washington Post A 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals panel has ruled that a 2002 law that aimed to prevent long waits for processing children’s immigration applications does not enable quick processing for all of these children once grown. Only youths under 21 can immigrate under parents' petitions. Trial set to begin in 'Irvine 11' student protest case - Los Angeles Times The trial of 10 young people from Muslim student groups, charged with misdemeanors for allegedly taking part in a protest against an Israeli ambassador's appearance at UC Irvine, is scheduled to begin this afternoon. Georgia immigration panel 'hate group' flap - Politico Georgia Gov. Nathan Deal has named Phil Kent, "the spokesman for a 'hate group' who once called African asylum seekers 'primitive peoples,' " to a panel charged with determining if a new state immigration law is properly enforced. 'Latin Alternative' on KCSN gives Latino music a new accent - Los Angeles Times "The Latin Alternative" is a 2-week-old program of Latin alternative music ranging "from neo-funk to cumbia-laced electronica." It airs on Cal State Northridge's radio station KCSN-FM (88.5) on Thursday nights from 9 to 10 p.m.

item.title: In the news this morning: The 'Irvine 11' trial, Latino kids going hungry, immigration talk at GOP debate, prosecutorial discretion, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Irvine 11's trial begins with both sides citing 1st Amendment - Los Angeles Times Prosecutors say the Muslim students on trial "shut down" Israeli Ambassador Michael Oren during a speech at UC Irvine in February 2010; defense attorneys argue that the students expressed political views in a legal protest and have the right to do so. Latino Kids Have Greater Chance Of Going Hungry In US - Fox News Latino A new report finds nearly one third of Latino children in the United States living in families that are experiencing food insecurity. Immigrant ground zero cleaners fight illnesses - Wall Street Journal Low-paid immigrant workers who helped clean offices near the site of the World Trade Center attacks ten years ago are still experiencing health problems as a result. Rick Perry grins, shrugs and swings away at Reagan Library GOP debate - Los Angeles Times Talk of border fences, employer crackdowns and other references to illegal immigration formed part of last night's debate among Republican presidential hopefuls in Simi Valley, along with many other issues. Immigration Shift Hasn't Trickled Down to Border Patrol - Texas Tribune While a federal memo in June urged immigration authorities to use prosecutorial discretion in the cases of certain immigrants, people who would be considered for it under the guidelines are still being detained and processed for deportation. Perry chats with Sheriff Joe - Politico The Arizona sheriff known for his hardline stance "tweeted at around 5 p.m. Eastern time, 'Just received phone call at my house from TX. Gov. Rick Perry. Had a great conversation especially about immigration and other matters.'"

item.title: In the news this morning: Deportations without due process, Latino Muslims on identity, Obama's uncle is released, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Many deportees unwittingly waive rights, report says - Los Angeles Times According to a report from the National Immigration Law Center, more than 160,000 immigrants signed what are called stipulated removals, many without understanding the documents and with no legal representation. Latino Muslims Define Their Identity 10 Years After 9/11 - Huffington Post A 2007 study showed that there were an estimated 2.5 million Latino Muslims living in the U.S. Many say they have become say they have become "ambassadors" for the religion in light of existing stereotypes. Obama's Uncle Released From Jail - Wall Street Journal Immigration officials aren't saying if 67-year-old Onyango Obama has posted bond, whether they are keeping track of the president's Kenyan-born uncle's whereabouts, or whether they are still seeking to deport him. ASUC passes bill in support of California DREAM Act - The Daily Californian (UC Berkeley) University of California student leaders have unanimously passed a bill urging Gov. Jerry Brown to sign a measure known as AB 131, which would grant access to public financial aid for undocumented students paying tuition. New Mexico Gov. Susana Martinez Confirms that Grandparents Were Undocumented - Fox News Latino Republican Gov. Susana Martinez, a champion of tighter restrictions that include barring undocumented immigrants from obtaining driver's licenses, has acknowledged that her paternal grandparents arrived illegally to the U.S. Obama's Hispanic support collapses - The Hill A new Gallup poll shows that President Obama's job approval rating from Latinos has slipped below 50 percent for the first time. Only 48 percent of Latinos polled show approval; 37 percent disapprove.

item.title: In the news this morning: The post-9/11 border buildup, new visa lottery lawsuit, NCLR calls off its Arizona boycott, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: For U.S.-Mexico border town, September 11 brought high wall - Reuters The post-9/11 buildup of border infrastructure by the U.S. as seen through the small ranching town of Naco, population 6,000, on the Mexican side of the border in the state of Sonora. Banco Popular Anglicizes its name to reach beyond Latinos - Los Angeles Times The Puerto Rican bank is changing its name to Popular Community Bank at its 24 branches in Southern California in hopes of appealing to more non-Latinos. Would-be immigrants file appeal in previously dismissed suit over botched visa lottery - The Washington Post A group of hopeful immigrants informed briefly this year that they had won visas in the annual federal visa lottery - only to learn there had been an error - has appealed again in court. Their last lawsuit was dismissed. National Council of La Raza calls off boycott - The Arizona Republic The National Council of La Raza announced that it is canceling its post-SB 1070 economic boycott of Arizona, saying it has already helped deter similar state laws, but it has imposed hardship on workers and businesses. Michele Bachmann Group Attacks Rick Perry on Immigration - Wall Street Journal A group supporting Republican presidential hopeful Michele Bachmann plans to run a radio spot this week attacking Texas Gov. Rick Perry, her rival, for being "too moderate on immigration." Michigan capital of Arab America reflects on 9/11 - The Associated Press The 10th anniversary of the World Trade Center attacks as observed in Dearborn, Michigan, the hub of Arab immigrant culture in the United States. It's a place where many residents and institutions have endured "a decade spent trying to deal with rising fear, misconceptions and suspicions."

item.title: In the news this morning: Crackdown on visa overstays, NCLR and the Arizona boycott, Rick Perry on immigration, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Broader security checks to reduce visa overstays - The Associated Press The Obama administration is looking for immigrants in the U.S. who have overstayed the terms of their visas, using a database that "automatically checks multiple national security, immigration and law enforcement databases at the same time." Arizona boycott over immigration law ends - Orange County Register More on the National Council of La Raza's announcement that it is ending its economic boycott of Arizona, which began after the passage of SB 1070. Cook County, Illinois, Bucks Immigration Enforcement Efforts - NPR One of the nation's largest jails has announced that it will no longer inmates for an extra period of time for immigration officials. Did Rick Perry show his liberal side? - CNN Texas governor and presidential candidate Rick Perry Perry displayed moderate attitudes on immigration yesterday during the inaugural CNN/Tea Party Debate. He supported a Texas law that grants in-state tuition to undocumented students and criticized the border fence.

item.title: In the news this morning: CIA investigates its role in NYPD's spying on Muslims, Russell Pearce recall, visa overstays, border bus tours, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: CIA investigates its role in NYPD programs that monitor Muslim communities, infiltrate mosques - The Washington Post The inspector general of the Central Intelligence Agency is investigating whether the agency broke the law in assisting the New York Police Department to build intelligence gathering programs that monitored Muslim communities. Author of Arizona's illegal immigration law to face recall election - Los Angeles Times Arizona state senator Russell Pearce, best known as the author of the controversial SB 1070 anti-illegal immigration law, is to face a recall election Nov. 8. Overstaying visa holders targeted by feds in terror sweep - New York Daily News More on a new federal push to identify visa overstayers. Agents will be checking databases and looking for national security risks, according to Homeland Security officials. Will there be a Rick 'Perry Plunge' over immigration? - The Miami Herald The Texas governor and presidential hopeful has become the target of hardliners for his defense of a bill he signed that would give undocumented student in-state tuition, and his criticism of the border fence. His immigration stance drew boos during a Tea Party candidates' debate earlier this week. Tour shows migrant life on the Arizona-Mexico border - CNN The Tucson, Arizona office of Gray Line Tours is offering a tour titled "Border Crisis: Fact and Fiction." The tour is "intended to allow tourists to see immigration at one of the hottest spots on the border." Will US extension of National Guard border presence deter immigration from Mexico? - Christian Science Monitor The Obama administration has decided to extend the deployment of 1,200 National Guard troops stationed along the border through the end of the year. The troops had been scheduled to leave on Sept. 30.

item.title: In the news today: A split over Arizona boycott, fewer immigrants getting New Mexico driver's licenses, Obama seeks Latino support, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Immigration Advocates Split over Arizona Boycott- New York Times The various activists who put an economic boycott of Arizona in place after the passage of SB 1070 last year are now divided over whether it ought to continue. The National Council of La Raza recently called off its boycott. Bachmann courts AZ's tough anti-immigrant sheriff - Boston Globe Minnesota representative and GOP presidential hopeful Michele Bachmann met yesterday in Phoenix with Maricopa County's Sheriff Joe Arpaio, whose endorsement is frequently sought by candidates in all types of races across the country. Immigrant licenses slowing in NM - Houston Chronicle The issuing of driver's licenses to immigrants has slowed in New Mexico since last year. But the decline in licenses issued grew steeper after Republican Gov. Susana Martinez, who pledged to further tighten the state's licensing policy, took office in January. Obama Seeks Latino Support For Jobs Bill - Huffington Post President Obama pitched his jobs bill to Latinos gathered yesterday night at a black-tie dinner for the Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute, a gathering attended by influential Latino leaders. Bill to improve data collection for AAPIs in California - Angry Asian Man Assembly Bill 1088 would require state labor and housing agencies to include the full spectrum of Asian American, Native Hawaiian and other Pacific Islander ethnicities in their data collection. The bill cleared the state legislature last week and has gone to the governor's desk.

item.title: In the news this morning: Visas for crime victims, task force blasts Secure Communities, Paris bans Muslim street prayers, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Southland officials reach out to human trafficking victims - Southern California Public Radio Immigrants who are crime victims are eligible for special categories of visas. Federal and regional immigration officials have been reaching out to victims of cross-border human trafficking. Major Boost in Trafficking and Crime Victims Visa Applications - Fox News Latino The number of trafficking and crime victims applying for special visas available to victims is crimes is up 28 percent from last year, according to immigration officials. Applicants say they learned of the visas from law enforcement. Deportation Program Sows Mistrust, U.S. is Told - New York Times An advisory task force on the Secure Communities immigration enforcement program "has sharply criticized immigration officials for creating confusion about its purposes and has found that the program had an 'unintended negative impact' on public safety." Paris ban on Muslim street prayers comes into effect - BBC News A ban on praying in the street, as practiced by French Muslims unable to find space in mosques, has taken effect in Paris. One official has offered the use of a disused fire brigade barracks as makeshift mosque. Cancer testing lags in Latinos with family history - Reuters According to a new California study, Latinos were less likely than white Americans to get screened for colon cancer, and much less likely when there was a family history. Pair charged in religious-asylum immigration scam - Los Angeles Times A Los Angeles-area immigration consultant and staff member could face jail time for a fraudulent immigration scheme based on bogus religious persecution claims, designed to win asylum for Chinese nationals.

item.title: In the news this morning: Obama and Latinos, the obstacles to learning English, immigrants in driver's license investigation, redistricting, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: With Hispanic support for Obama waning, could Latino vote be up for grabs in 2012? - The Washington Post Recent Gallup polling has President Obama's approval rating among Latinos down to 48 percent, the lowest during his presidency, and a significant drop from the 60 percent rating he had among Latinos as recently as January. GOP focuses on minority outreach - Sacramento Bee In an attempt to appeal to Latino voters, the California Republican Party on invited Latinos to a town-hall style event in Los Angeles on Saturday. But immigration continues to be an awkward sticking point. Putting our minds to helping immigrants learn English - Los Angeles Times Columnist Steve Lopez on immigrant parents learning English, the role it plays in parental school involvement, and the obstacles to parents' learning and access to classes. Massachusetts investigates immigrants who obtained state driver's licenses via Arizona - The Boston Globe Immigrants who were unable to obtain driver's licenses in Massachusetts due to a language barrier found it easier to travel to Arizona to obtain them; now, hundreds of people who did this are being investigated by state police. Friends of U.S., Terrorists in Eyes of Law - New York Times An estimated 4,000 immigration cases are on hold as immigration officials try to figure out how to process people who were previously granted political asylum or refugee status, but whose organizational ties ban them from permanent residency. Many belonged to groups once backed by the U.S. government. Could Texas' Redistricting Leave Latinos Behind? - NPR Texas will pick up four new seats in the U.S. House of Representatives next year, but civil rights groups and the U.S. Justice Department have said there are concerns about whether the redistricting process there could put Latino voters at a political disadvantage.

item.title: In the news today: More than a million deported, the 'Irvine 11' trial, farmers fear effects of Alabama immigration law, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: It's Official: Obama Has Deported More Than A Million Unauthorized Immigrants - Mother Jones "The Obama administration had deported about 1.06 million as of September 12, against 1.57 million in Bush's two full presidential terms." Analysis: Obama deportations raise immigration policy questions - Reuters More on the controversy and questions raised over the Obama administration's deportation of more than a million people in the last two and a half years, despite the president saying he backs immigration reform. 'Irvine 11' accused of censorship - Los Angeles Times A prosecutor in the trial of ten Muslim students, being tried for disrupting an Israeli ambassador's speech during a UC Irvine appearance last year, accused them of acting as "censors" in closing arguments yesterday. The defense has argued they acted within their rights. Farmers say Ala immigration law could cost crops - Houston Chronicle Alabama farmers have asked state legislators to make emergency changes to the state's strict new anti-illegal immigration law, saying millions of dollars' worth of crops are at risk for lack of workers. US reviews care of deported Haitian who died - Wall Street Journal A review of medical records has concluded that a Haitian man who suffered from cholera-like symptoms and died in his homeland after the U.S. deported him had no pre-existing health problems.

item.title: In the news this morning: FBI counterterrorism training, border report alleges mistreatment, undocumented children at risk, E-Verify, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Report: FBI Counterterrorism Trainings Paint Muslims As 'Violent' And 'Radical' : The Two-Way - NPR The evolving controversy surrounding how the FBI has trained its agents on the subject of Islam, most recently over the incendiary presentations made by one intelligence analyst. Border agents mistreat migrants, report says - The Arizona Republic A report by a humanitarian activist group that interviewed thousands of people caught crossing illegally by the Border Patrol claims that agents threw migrants' food on the floor, confiscated medicine and used racial slurs. The agency says such behavior isn't tolerated. Risks Seen for Children of Illegal Immigrants - New York Times Children whose parents are undocumented, or who grow up without legal status themselves, are at risk for "'uniformly negative' effects on their social development from early childhood until they become adults," according to a new Harvard report. E-Verify Bill Against Illegal Workers in Doubt - Wall Street Journal Fearing it could hurt business, a bipartisan group of critics in Washington, D.C. has come out against a bill proposed by Judiciary Chairman Lamar Smith (R., Texas) that would require all employers to use E-Verify, an electronic database used to check whether new hires are eligible to work in the U.S. Half of All U.S. Latinos Live In The Country's Most Polluted Cities - Huffington Post A report released this week finds nearly one in every two Latinos in the U.S. living in areas with unhealthy air quality. The Associated Press: Italian police, migrants clash at holding center - The Associated Press Protesting forced repatriations, migrants have clashed with police on the tiny Italian island of Lampedusa after setting fire to their overcrowded holding center. Tens of thousands of refugees from North Africa have arrived on the island since the start of political revolts in the region.

item.title: In the news this morning: Ethnicity's role in New York police spying case, E-Verify bill clears House committee, day laborer ordinance, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: More cases of NYPD ethnic spying exposed - CBS News Ethnicity played a role in the surveillance conducted by New York police on Muslim neighborhoods, according to documents and interviews; Moroccan immigrants were one of the groups targeted. Asian American groups enter fight over L.A. County supervisor districts - Los Angeles Times A coalition of Asian Pacific Islander groups backs a plan that would create a second Latino-majority district on the five-member county board. Loitering or looking for work? Redondo Beach’s day laborers can stay - Southern California Public Radio KPCC's Patt Morrison show on a federal appeals court decision regarding a Redondo Beach anti-solicitation ordinance aimed at day laborers. The court ruled last week that the measure is unconstitutional. House committee passes E-Verify bill, rejects ag worker amendment - Southeast Farm Press The House Judiciary Committee has approved a bill mandating the use of E-Verify, an online database to verify employees' eligibility to work, for all U.S. employers. An amendment proposing an agricultural worker program was rejected. Italian Police Clash With North African Immigrants in Lampedusa- Bloomberg Dozens were injured after Italian police and North African migrants, protesting their possible repatriation, clashed on the Italian island of Lampedusa. Tens of thousands have fled North Africa in the wake of political revolts, taking refuge on the island.

item.title: In the news this morning: E-Verify bill faces challenges, allegations of mistreatment at border, DHS reviews Secure Communities, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: House immigration status-check bill faces tough road – USA Today A bill requiring private businesses to use a federal database to check the legal status of job applicants has made it through the House Judiciary Committee, but it's expected to have a difficult time making it past the full House and the Senate. Ad targeting legal immigration airs during GOP debate - The Hill Video of the ad that aired during yesterday's GOP candidates' debate by the immigration-restriction group NumbersUSA, which argued that "those coming to the United States legally are taking jobs away from Americans." Report: Border Patrol abuses widespread - CNN More on the recently released report from a humanitarian advocacy group based on nearly 13,000 testimonies, in which immigrants said they were mistreated in ways that included sleep deprivation, death threats and psychological abuse. Homeland's screening policy of illegal immigrants flawed, report says – USA Today According to a review conducted by a Homeland Security advisory council, the controversial Secure Communities fingerprint sharing program may need to be suspended until problems with the program are worked out. Perry's immigrant-education stand draws fire - The Washington Post Texas Gov. Rick Perry’s support for a law allowing undocumented students in Texas to obtain cheaper in-state tuition is eroding some of his support as he tries to remain a frontrunner in GOP presidential race.

item.title: In the news this morning: Immigrants hope for last-minute deportation reprieves, 'Irvine 11' plan an appeal, Latino children and ADHD, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Amid new guidelines, Va. woman's deportation case comes down to the last minute - The Washington Post Immigrants in the final stages of the deportation process hope for reprieves under guidelines announced by the Obama administration last month, intended to spare those deemed a low priority for removal. Lawyers at 'town hall': UC Muslims will appeal - The Orange County Register The Muslim college students convicted last week of disrupting an Israeli ambassador's speech at UC Irvine and their attorneys gathered at a "town hall" meeting this weekend to talk about the case; they plan to file an appeal. Latino children show low ADHD rate - The Boston Globe Statistics from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show that roughly 3.9 percent of Latino children over the past decade were reported by parents to have been diagnosed with ADHD, vs. 7.8 percent of white children and 6.3 percent of black children. Some believe that different attitudes about children's behavior play a part. Report: higher smog risk for U.S. Latinos - Miami Herald A new report shows Latinos in the U.S. enduring a disproportionately higher health risk from air pollution, with nearly half living in the 25 U.S. cities most polluted by ground-level ozone. Arizona backs off monitoring teachers' accents - San Francisco Chronicle After almost a decade of monitoring classrooms to check on teachers' articulation, Arizona recently called off "its accent police" after a federal investigation of possible civil rights violations. Immigration questions dog Perry after debate - CNN Texas Gov. Rick Perry's support for a state bill allowing undocumented students to pay in-state college tuition rates has landed him in hot water with fellow Republicans, possibly jeopardizing his presidential run.

item.title: In the news this morning: UC Berkeley's 'diversity bake sale,' minorities and LA redistricting, in-state tuition for RI undocumented students, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Berkeley Republicans' 'Pay-by-Race' Bake Sale Still On - ABC News A protest by Republican students that's being called an "Increase Diversity" bake sale, with the highest prices charged to white men, is still set for Thursday in spite of criticism from students who have called the event racist. Rhode Island gives in-state tuition to illegal immigrant students - Los Angeles Times Education officials in Rhode Island have voted to allow in-state tuition at public colleges and universities for undocumented students. API Groups Endorse L.A. County Redistricting Plan - Rafu Shimpo With the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors set to decide on redrawn district boundaries today, a coalition of Asian Pacific Islander organizations is supporting one plan it says would give these communities a stronger political voice. Latinos in L.A. County demand more representation - Fox News Latino Latinos, meanwhile, are underrepresented in comparison with their population on the county board, with only one Latina supervisor. New York High School Helps Immigrant 'Kids' Adapt - NPR On Brooklyn's International High School, a public school for recent immigrants.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Chancellor Robert J Birgeneau ($500,000 salary) of University of California Berkeley displaces qualified for public university education at Cal. Californians for $50,600 payment by FOREIGN students.
The University of California Berkeley, ranked # 70 Forbes, is not increasing enrollment. $50,600 tuition FOREIGN students are accepted by Birgeneau at the expense of qualified instate students.
UC Regent Chairwoman Lansing and President Yudof agree discriminating against instate Californians for admission to UC Berkeley. Birgeneau, Yudof, Lansing need to answer to Californians.
Your opinion makes a difference; email UC Board of Regents marsha.kelman@ucop.edu

item.title: In the news this morning: LA County board votes down second Latino-majority district, deportation issue goes to Supreme Court, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: LA County supervisors reject 2nd Latino district - Southern California Public Radio The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors has decided against creating a second supervisorial district with a majority of Latino voters. Latino civil rights activists have said they will file a lawsuit, noting that Latinos are politically underrepresented in the county. Supreme Court to decide immigrant deportation issue - Los Angeles Times The U.S. Supreme Court will hear a case that concerning whether the government may deport undocumented immigrants who arrived in the country as children, and whose parents became legal residents. Federal judge set to rule on legal challenges to Alabama's tough new immigration law - The Washington Post A federal judge will rule on lawsuits challenging the constitutionality of a stringent new anti-illegal immigration law in Alabama; a ruling is expected by Wednesday. Arizona Woman Fighting for Health Care for Immigrant Husband Who Suffered Brain Damage - Fox News Latino  The U.S. citizen's husband is an undocumented immigrant who was in the final stages of obtaining permanent legal resident status, his wife says, with his interview scheduled for this week. The state won't cover his medical costs. Arizona sheriff launches a political committee so he can donate money to federal candidates - The Washington Post Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Phoenix is launching a political action committee in order to raise money for federal candidates who share his tough-on-illegal-immigration views.

item.title: In the news this morning: How companies profit from immigration enforcement, Latino kids living in poverty, ICE arrests almost 3,000, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Companies Use Immigration Crackdown to Turn a Profit - The New York Times It's not just CCA and The GEO Group who have benefited from immigrant detention and immigration crackdowns in the U.S. and elsewhere; there are companies around the world that profit. Hispanic kids are the largest group of children living in poverty - The Washington Post According to a new study, Latino kids are now the largest group of children living in poverty. It is the first time in U.S. history that poor white children have been outnumbered by poor children of another race or ethnicity. Judge Upholds Key Parts of Alabama Immigration Law - Wall Street Journal A federal judge yesterday upheld key parts of a stringent Alabama anti-illegal immigration law, rejecting the federal government's request to block them. The decision bodes well for states pushing their own immigration laws. Perry dials it down on immigration - Politico During a CBNC appearance, Texas governor and presidential hopeful Rick Perry toned down his approach. He's been criticized for his support of in-state tuition for undocumented students. After promising to target criminals, DHS announces arrests of thousands of criminal immigrants - The Washington Post  The Obama administration apprehended close to 3,000 immigrants for deportation last week in a nationwide sweep, announced yesterday. More than half had been convicted of at least one felony.

item.title: In the news this morning: Repatriation program criticized, more Latinos identify as Native American, Alabama law confuses schools, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: U.S. makes deported immigrants take the long way home - Los Angeles Times The "Alien Transfer Exit Program" tries to disrupt immigration patterns, lessening the chances of another illegal crossing. But critics say it makes already vulnerable migrants even more so. More Latinos identify as Native American, census shows - CNN Between 2000 and 2010, the number of Latinos who identified themselves on census forms as Native American grew from 407,073 to 685,150. Some attribute the increase to more immigration from indigenous regions of Latin America, and to Latinos identifying ties to native roots. Fatal Accident Puts Focus on Deportation Program - New York Times A fatal accident involving an undocumented immigrant, accused of driving under the influence, has prompted outrage over immigration enforcement in Massachusetts. Mexican firefighter who helped at ground zero dies - Wall Street Journal A Mexican firefighter who assisted Latino immigrants sickened after cleaning buildings at the site of the 2001 World Trade Center attacks has himself died at 49; Rafael Hernandez had been diagnosed with chronic respiratory conditions linked to exposure to Ground Zero. College student won't be deported to Bangladesh, for now - Los Angeles Times A young woman who left Bangladesh as an infant and grew up in New York has won a temporary reprieve from immigration officials, shortly before she was due to be deported. Alabama immigration law leaves schools gripped by uncertainty - Christian Science Monitor One of the controversial provisions of an Alabama anti-illegal immigration law upheld this week by a federal judge involves forcing public schools to check the immigration status of new students.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: RMSI is a world leader when it comes to medical air evacuation. The short term for this is Medevac (Medical and Evacuation brought together). Some however call it Medivac, which should be the same two words brought together, however with Medi and Vac from evacuation. However the last term is less correct, as it does not take the first letter from Evacuation.

item.title: In the news this morning: School absences tied to Alabama law, SB 1070 awaits Supreme Court review this term, deported border crossers, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Ala. immigration law marked by Hispanic school absences – USA Today A strict new Alabama anti-illegal immigration law, key parts of which were recently upheld in court, has already prompted hundreds of children to be absent from school. Among other things, there is a provision that requires schools to check students' immigration status. As Supreme Court Begins New Term, Immigration Looms Large - New America Media Among the many things the U.S. Supreme Court will consider as it begins its new term on Monday is Arizona’s controversial SB 1070 anti-illegal immigration law, parts of which were blocked by a judge last year. Crossing over, and Over - New York Times Migrant shelters along the U.S.-Mexico border are filled with seasoned border crossers, often deportees who take ever-greater risks to return to their families in the U.S., which they consider home. Even with in-state tuition rates, illegal-immigrant students face barriers to employment - Washington Post Without an immediate pathway to legal status, many graduates can't be legally hired under current federal immigration law. Richard S. Amador Sr. obituary: Expert in community economic development dies at 75 - Los Angeles Times Amador, the son of migrant workers, founded East L.A.'s CHARO Community Development Corp., which created thousands of jobs and was ranked one of the top Latino nonprofits in the nation. He also worked in President Lyndon B. Johnson's Office of Economic Opportunity.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
After 1990 more people have covertly arrived here than any time since immigration numbers have been recorded. In the previous 20 years, immigration has exploded to over 1 million newcomers a year, that it is three times the conventional standard. Immigration is not just one issue that profoundly affects our children and grandchildren, but goes far beyond today’s challenges we must deal with such as jobs, the economy and loss of revenue from paying equally for our uninsured Americans but illegal aliens as well. Our countries population has more than doubled from 203 million in 1970 and an impending 439 million in 2050, according to the Census Bureau. Immigration is estimated to cause eighty-two percent of propagation between 2005 and 2050 as estimated by The Pew Hispanic Center. Congress has caused this radical population, without thinking of future consequences or the incessant extortion of U.S. taxpayers by the IRS to pay for these people--illegal and illegal.
Yesterdays immigrants came with nothing; expecting nothing. But those illegal immigrants, who have come here since 1986, expect free welfare and public assistance and demanding even more through demonstration in our streets. These are economic illegal aliens, made easy to come here through porous borders and even less internal enforcement. $113 Billion dollars a year and climbing, doesn’t seem that much under the present doldrums of a 14.7 Trillion dollar U.S. deficit? But this money should not be going to foreigners, when America have their own crushing poverty, within its states? A good beginning to the long road back, is by all patriotic citizens or legalized residents insisting that Congress adopt Lamar Smiths mandated E-Verify bill (H.R. 2885), identified as the “Legal Workforce Act" . Contact your own local Senator or Representative or federal politician at 202-224-3121.
The consequences of illegal alien workers being hired will be alleviated by turning the tables on less than honorable business owners, who are stealing jobs from American workers to buttress their enormous earnings. There are no short cuts in this massive problem as a way back to national sovereignty or the way our government is suppose to work. A failure to secure our borders is not an option, or to enforce the laws of the 1986 Immigration Control and Reform Act. None of this illegal population would have happened if previous administrations had enforced all policies. The “Legal Workforce Act” has the intensity, to reject those illegal workers and open many jobs for citizens and permanent residents. Like any other developed country with growing industries, we always have the inducement of a good place to live, if you qualify for a special preference visa. Only the highest eligible skills should be expedited, and those who are considered—ECONOMIC--aliens must be turned away.
THIS IS NOT JUST ABOUT STATE IMMIGRATION POLICING LAWS IN ARIZONA, ALABAMA, GEORGIA, UTAH OR ANY OTHER STATE SOVEREIGNTY. IT IS EVERY AMERICAN STATES PROBLEM AND ITS RESIDENTS. IT’S NOT JUST A RICK PERRY ISSUE, MITT ROMNEY, OR ANY PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL; IT'S EVERY AMERICAN PROBLEM WHO STILL REMAINS JOBLESS. IT'S A GROWING CATASTROPHE FOR ALL OF US, WHO ARE FORCED BY LAW TO SUPPORT HEALTH TREATMENT, EDUCATION AND A WIDE CORNUCOPIA OF PUBLIC SERVICES TO FOREIGN NATIONALS. WHOEVER ARRIVES IN THE WHITE HOUSE MUST HOLD THE SOLID IDEALS OF THE TEA PARTY. “…GOVERNMENT OF THE PEOPLE, BY THE PEOPLE, FOR THE PEOPLE...”
by President Abraham Lincoln, June 1, 1865
We can no longer afford the expense of illegal entries, which have arrived here by the millions adding to the impoverished amongst the jobless Americans. This country is being handicapped on all levels of government, by the insistence from both political parties that we must support everyone who enters this country. The costs have spiraled to over 100 billion a year, with public assistance. Only the TEA PARTY has guaranteed to its millions of members that our immigration laws will be strictly held to the highest degree. The border must be our first line of protection against the criminals of every designation, and those who come here through the impaired fencing. E-Verify bill (H.R. 2885), recognized as the “Legal Workforce Act" can be the second line of defense for in-house audits, to siphon out foreign workers. A third line of defense is the patriotic American who informs ICE at of irregularities in all occupations at 1-866-DHS-2ICE (866-347-2423). SEE SOMETHING? DO SOMETHING?
This does not mean just a laborer working for a greedy contractor, but even middle management in a factory. Also stand with Secure Communities that any individual who is processed in police custody, is fingerprinted and checked through ICE and homeland Security databases. American Patrol, a pro-sovereignty group hosts on its website, a daily headline from thousands of newspapers, dealing with corruption in politics and immigration. NumbersUSA has internal firsthand knowledge of Congressional happenings and immigration. Judicial Watch reveals the corruption in all Washington agencies, along with the same resonating in each states capitol.
A federal judge's resolution last week left Alabama's strict new immigration law largely intact is already having a key impact throughout the state, as hundreds of children stayed away from school. The state's anti-immigration law is now in effect, including a provision that requires schools to check the immigration status of students. My guess is that thousands of illegal families will be pursuing a new home, such as the Sanctuary state of California or any state where immigration laws are lax and remain unenforced.
One Old Vet saying, “Stand next to me and you’ll never stand alone.”
MY EARLIER BLOGS: http://brittanicus-enoughisenough.blogspot.com

item.title: In the news this morning: Immigrants begin leaving Alabama, nearly half of NYC business owners are foreign born, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: After Ruing, Hispanics Flee an Alabama Town - New York Times Immigrants from Latin America living in Alabama have been packing up and leaving the state since last week, after a federal judge upheld key parts of a new state anti-illegal immigration law deemed the nation's strictest. Immigrants Own 48% of N.Y.'s Small Businesses - New York Times A census-based study published Monday found that more than 69,000 of New York City's business owners — almost half — are foreign born. They run companies in every economic sector, but are concentrated in certain industries like dry cleaning, taxi services and grocery stores. Lawyers seek NYPD spy docs as lawmakers duck issue - The Associated Press Civil rights lawyers have asked a federal judge to force the New York Police Department to turn over records about clandestine police programs that monitored daily life in Muslim neighborhoods. Alabama argues immigration law should stay in place - al.com Attorneys defending Alabama's new immigration law argued in a court filing yesterday that the law should not be delayed pending an appeal. Last Thursday, a day after a federal judge upheld key provisions, a group of 36 plaintiffs asked the court to stay the law until there is an appeals court ruling. Immigration law author tells farmers: No changes - Houston Chronicle Alabama state Sen. Scott Beason, a Republican supporter of Alabama's stringent new immigration law, told tomato farmers yesterday that he won't change the law. The farmers told him that their crops are rotting in the field for lack of labor and they risk losing their farms.

item.title: In the news this morning: Napolitano promotes enforcement strategy, John and Ken vs. immigration advocates, AL law in schools, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Napolitano to promote DHS work on immigration - The Associated Press Department of Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano is delivering a speech today at American University in Washington D.C. to discuss what she calls the "smart, effective enforcement" of U.S. immigration laws. The Obama administration continues to reiterate that its focus is on criminals. On the Media: KFI's John and Ken and the California Dream Act - Los Angeles Times Last month, the immigration-restriction radio duo urged fans to call the spokesman for the Coalition for Humane Immigrant Rights of Los Angeles, an immigrant advocacy group, releasing his phone number and subjecting the man to a barrage of hate calls. Critics say they went too far and want them off the air. Suit claims non-Hispanic hotel workers fired in CO - BusinessWeek Former employees at a Colorado hotel are alleging they were fired and replaced with Latino workers because the business owners thought white and non-Latino workers were "lazy," according to a federal lawsuit. Pennsylvania Enters Immigration Debate with Undocumented Immigrant Bill - Fox News Latino A legislative committee in Pennsylvania has approved a state bill that would revoke the professional license of anyone who hires undocumented workers. Alabama: Students don’t need birth certificates - Politico State officials, trying to calm parents after a stringent new immigration law went into effect, are saying that children will be enrolled even if they don’t have birth certificates. The Alabama state law requires schools to check students' immigration status. So far, there has been a rash of absences. 1 dead, others hurt in boat full of suspected illegal immigrants - Los Angeles Times One person has died and others have received emergency treatment after a suspected human smuggling boat washed up on a San Diego beach.

item.title: In the news this morning: Alabama's 'humanitarian crisis,' Arabs embrace Steve Jobs, maritime smuggling deaths, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Is Alabama immigration law creating a 'humanitarian crisis'? - Christian Science Monitor With what's considered to be the nation's strictest state immigration law now in effect, it's estimated that some 2,000 Latino students didn't attend school Monday. A provision requiring schools to check students' immigration status was among those upheld by a federal judge last week. Arabs embrace Steve Jobs and the Syrian connection - The Economic Times Many Syrians were unaware until recently that Apple founder Steve Jobs, who died yesterday, was the biological son of a Syrian immigrant father, put up for adoption shortly after his birth. But they were quick to embrace Jobs when news broke of his death. Some online have called him "a great Arab American." Software Helps Mexican-Americans Trace Their Roots - Fox News Latino Software with 1930 census date from Mexico will be going online, allowing descendants of Mexican immigrants to search for their ancestors. 2 illegal immigrants die in San Diego-area maritime accidents - Los Angeles Times There were two deaths related to maritime illegal immigration traffic yesterday in San Diego. One man was found dead inside a smuggling boat; the other died as migrants tried to swim around the border fence. Georgia farmers losing millions to anti-migrant law - Fox News Latino Two new studies show that Georgia's agricultural industry lost tens of millions of dollars in the last harvest. Many farmers say they will plant less next season due to a labor shortage triggered by a strict new state immigration law.

item.title: In the news this morning: Alabama ag director looks to inmates, airline sued over hijab discrimination, 'John and Ken' boycott, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Ala.: Inmates can replace Hispanic farmhands - Politico The head of Alabama's agriculture department is looking to inmate labor as "a short-term solution to the sudden labor shortage that has hit Alabama since enforcement of its illegal immigration law kicked in." Muslim woman removed from Southwest flight sues - USA Today A U.S. citizen graduate student has sued Southwest Airlines, alleging she was discriminated against when she was removed from a flight last spring because she was wearing an Islamic head covering. Immigrant rights group plans boycott of "John and Ken" radio show - Los Angeles Times A coalition of Latino and immigrant rights groups says it plans to proceed with a boycott of the KFI-AM radio show. The show's hosts, who speak out against illegal immigration, gave out the number of a local advocate who in turn was barraged with hate calls. Latino Homeownership Up 2% Despite Record Low Housing Numbers - Fox News Latino Minority home ownership in the U.S. has risen slightly over the past decade. The biggest rise has been in in Latino home ownership, which in 10 years grew from 45.7 percent to 47.3 percent. Cuomo: NY to translate forms into other languages - Wall Street Journal New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo has ordered state agencies to translate documents and also to provide interpreters in six languages for immigrants who are seeking public services. Some Latinos See Obama 'Betrayal' On Immigration - National Public Radio The latest Gallup poll shows that President Obama's support among Latino voters has fallen to 48 percent, a new low.

item.title: In the news this morning: California Dream Act signed into law, SB 185 vetoed, Alabama immigrants make worst-case plans for kids, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Jerry Brown signs California Dream Act - Los Angeles Times On Saturday, California Gov. Jerry Brown signed into law a bill that will allow undocumented college students to apply for state-funded financial aid, which they previously had no access to. Brown vetoes bill letting schools consider race - Sacramento Bee Another California bill called SB 185, which would have allowed for race, ethnicity and gender to be weighed in college admissions, was vetoed by the governor Saturday. Immigrants fearing deportation make plans for kids - The Associated Press Fearing the worst in light of Alabama's strict new immigration law, some undocumented immigrant parents are asking friends, relatives, co-workers and other acquaintances to take their children in the event they are arrested or deported. Interactive: How Latinos Are Reshaping Communities - NPR Over the past decade, the story of population growth in the United States has been defined largely by how Latinos have become the nation's largest minority. ICE paints bleak picture of detention system - Houston Chronicle Internal documents from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement's Office of Detention Oversight detail an often bleak scenario inside the nation's immigrant detention facilities, with detainees in some "lacking access to quality medical care or even clean underwear."

item.title: In the news this morning: NYPD spied on Muslim students, more Latino kids affected by poverty, CA immigrant laws buck national trend, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: NYPD infiltrated Muslim student groups for intel - CBS News Investigators have been infiltrating Muslim student groups at Brooklyn College and other schools in New York City, according to police documents. Latinos Lead Nation In Childhood Poverty - NPR An interview with Mark Lopez, associate director of the Pew Hispanic Center and co-author of a recent report on how Latino children now make up the majority of poor children in the U.S., with their families hit hard by the recession. Immigration reform tops public policy issues - The Packer The House Judiciary Committee has approved mandatory E-Verify legislation, but its prospects in the full House are uncertain, as are the chances for attachment of a farm guest worker amendment. Illegal immigrants get boost in new California laws - San Jose Mercury News As other states such as Alabama push tough immigration laws, "California took a leap in the other direction this weekend when Gov. Jerry Brown signed a host of bills that make the nation's biggest state one of the most accepting of immigrants living here illegally." Immigration fight moves to next round in Atlanta court - Fox News Today, the state of Alabama is set to make its argument for all portions of a stringent new anti-illegal immigration law to go into effect; key provisions, but not the entire law, were recently upheld by a federal judge.

item.title: In the news this morning: Work stoppage protests in Alabama, bilingual babies, migration from Central America drops, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Ala. Hispanics Organizing Campaign Against Law - ABC News Large poultry plants are planning to close or scale back operations due to a work stoppage being promoted by Latinos in Alabama and their supporters in protest of a strict new state immigration law. Federal indictment charges 12 with running NYC-based immigration fraud mill - The Washington Post The indictment charges a dozen people with "operating a massive immigration fraud mill through a New York City law practice." Hearing Bilingual: How Babies Sort Out Language - New York Times New research shows a difference between the ways in which monolingual babies and bilingual babies recognize a language and its sounds. Muslim comic series aims to break through in US - The Associated Press U.S.-educated psychologist Naif Al-Mutawa's comic book "The 99" has led to a TV series with 26 half-hour episodes, expected to be released early next year in more than 50 countries. Former Astronaunt, Son of Immigrants, Runs for Congress - Sacramento Bee Former NASA astronaut Jose Hernandez announced yesterday that he will be running for U.S. Congress in California's newly created 10th District. Immigration from Central America to Mexico Plummets, Mexican Official Says - Fox News Latino The number of Central Americans crossing into Mexico illegally dropped from 433,000 in 2005 to 140,000 in 2010, a trend that has continued into this year, according to a Mexican government official.

item.title: In the news this morning: Alabama protests affect poultry industry, slower times on the border, another state immigration law challenged, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Hispanics skip work to protest immigration law - Forbes A work stoppage yesterday held to protest a strict new state immigration law appeared largest in northeast Alabama, the hub of the state's profitable poultry industry. At least a half-dozen chicken processing plants were closed or scaled back their operations. At the Border, on the Night Watch - New York Times As the number of illegal border crossings has dropped significantly in recent years, shifts have become quieter for the Border Patrol agents who work the line, even in Arizona. Groups sue to halt South Carolina's new immigration law - Reuters A coalition of civil rights groups has filed suit in federal court to block a new South Carolina anti-illegal immigration law, one of several recent state immigration crackdowns taking place in the South. Fla. Sen. Marco Rubio sidesteps immigration debate - Miami Herald The Cuban American freshman senator from Florida, seen by some as a future GOP presidential hopeful, has been steering clear of discussing immigration issues. Ken Salazar urges more Latino-themed national parks, sites - Washington Post The Obama administration's interior secretary has urged the National Park Service to identify more sites related to women's and minority history in the U.S. that could be added to the National Register of Historic Places, or preserved as national parks or landmarks.

item.title: In the news this morning: Racial profiling lawsuit in Glendale, Brown defends CA Dream Act, immigration and the GOP, fear in Alabama, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: ACLU files suit over alleged racial profiling of Glendale students - Los Angeles Times The lawsuit alleges that about 55 Latino students at Hoover High School in Glendale, Calif. were illegally detained, searched and questioned. Governor Defends the DREAM Act - NBC Los Angeles California Gov. Jerry Brown defended the bill he signed last weekend, which allows public financial aid for undocumented students, at a conference yesterday. "Having a top kid become a college scientist or professor is better than sweeping floors," he said. Dayton, Ohio approves plan to be an immigrant-friendly city - Reuters The city has approved a plan to become an "immigrant-friendly city," aimed at helping immigrants in the U.S. legally navigate the system. A Road Map for Immigrant Parents – New York Times The New York Immigration Coalition has announced a project that it hopes can increase immigrant parents' involvement in the city’s public school system. It establishes a network of resource centers to help immigrants better understand the U.S. educational system. The GOP's Immigration Fixation - Wall Street Journal The rate of illegal immigration has slowed to a near trickle, yet the issue "remains bitterly contentious" in the GOP presidential candidates' race. Why? Alabama Immigrants To DOJ: 'The Situation Here Is Very Dire' - Huffington Post At a forum attended by federal Department of Justice officials, people spoke up about the strict new state anti-illegal immigration law: "Some immigrants said they were unsure how to get to work, because renewing their license plates would now require them to show immigration papers." Others feared sending kids to school.

item.title: In the news this morning: Parts of Alabama law blocked, diversity and the 'Occupy' movement, CA law prohibits forced E-Verify use, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Parts of Alabama immigration law blocked by federal appeals court - CNN Among the provisions of the new state law blocked by an appeals court Friday is one requiring schools to check students' immigration status. However, a provision allowing police to check for immigration status remains. Occupy protesters eye diversity as movement grows - Boston While the crowds of protesters in New York have been relatively diverse, in many cities, the "Occupy" protesters have been predominantly white. New California law bars E-Verify requirement for businesses - Los Angeles Times Local ordinances in cities like Temecula, Murrieta and Lake Elsinore that required businesses to use E-Verify, an online program for checking workers' immigration status, appear to be hung up now that a new state law prohibits the state, cities and counties from forcing private employers to use it. FBI anti-Muslim bias charged - UPI Community and civil rights groups in the Bay Area are charging that the training received by some FBI agents is biased and anti-Islamic, leading to prejudice in their dealings with Muslims. U.S. firms urge action on skilled immigrant reform - Reuters U.S. firms and multinationals are upset over difficulties in securing visas for foreign workers, which "effectively require them to keep high-skilled workers abroad instead of expanding operations in the United States."

item.title: In the news this morning: Obama's immigration policies protested, Alabama's lack of workers, anti-Latino hate crimes rise, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Latinos to protest Obama's immigration policies - CNN Activists are planning a national "day of action" in 10 cities to protest President Obama's immigration enforcement policies and demand an end to the controversial Secure Communities fingerprint sharing program. Test fails to replace immigrant laborers with U.S. citizens in Alabama - Boston Herald After experimenting with hiring unemployed Americans to pick crops, the head of an agriculture trade group in the state has said resident Americans "lack the physical stamina and the mental toughness" for the job. Anti-Latino Hate Crimes Rise As Immigration Debate Intensifies - Huffington Post Studies are indicating that several high-profile incidents of violence toward Latinos in recent years are not isolated crimes, but part of a larger trend. Report: More deportees criminals - Politico Of the more than 400,000 people deported last year, 55 percent had criminal convictions, some more serious than others. The Obama administration has stated that deporting people with offense records is a priority. Top Hispanic Congressman Slams Herman Cain's Illegal Immigration Remedy - ABC News GOP presidential hopeful Herman Cain's "joke" about building an electrified border fence has met with a rebuke from Rep. Charles Gonzalez, chair of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, who warned Cain against "using his popularity to irresponsibly stoke public opinion."

item.title: In the news this morning: Another year of record deportations, Secure Communities and Latinos, immigration in the GOP debate, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Latinos Said to Bear Weight of a Deportation Program - New York Times A new report finds that Latinos are disproportionately affected by the Secure Communities immigration enforcement program, and that of the roughly 226,000 immigrants who have been deported under it, about a third have spouses or children who are United States citizens. US federal government says it deported a record nearly 400,000 people in the past year - The Washington Post U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement announced yesterday that the agency deported nearly 400,000 people during the fiscal year that ended in September, the largest number in the agency’s history. About 55 percent were reported to have a criminal conviction. Republicans' border talk poses risk with Latinos - Reuters GOP presidential hopefuls talked tough about illegal immigration during a debate yesterday in Nevada, but some of it may not go down well with the growing number of Latino voters in the state. Sparks Fly Over Immigration at GOP Debate - Fox News Latino Republican presidential hopefuls Mitt Romney and Texas Gov. Rick Perry clashed in last night's debate over immigration, particularly over former Massachusetts governor Romney's admission years ago that he once unknowingly hired an undocumented worker. Fear in Ala. towns over tough immigration law – USA Today From the story: "We've seen so many families leave. They just drive off in the middle of the night," says Miguel, 54, a Guatemalan native. "Pretty soon, all Hispanics here will leave. When that happens, we'll leave, too."

item.title: In the news this morning: Deportation reviews to begin, 'Irvine 11' students file appeal, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Napolitano: Deportation reviews to begin shortly - CNN Homeland Security secretary Janet Napolitano said that officials will begin a small "pilot" review of immigration cases in the coming weeks. The Obama administration promised in August that it would review some 300,000 cases involving immigrants deemed a "low priority" for deportation. Comments on Immigration Alienate Some Hispanics - New York Times With a growing Latino population in battlegound states, will Republican candidates' talk of building border fences and turning off “magnets” like college tuition aid for undocumented students turn off the Latino voters they need to win? Irvine 11 students appeal conviction - Los Angeles Times Ten Muslim students who were convicted last month of disrupting a speech by the Israeli ambassador at UC Irvine last year have filed an appeal; their case, watched closely by civil rights advocates, ignited a national debate over free speech. D.C. won't cooperate with federal immigration enforcement, mayor says - The Washington Post Washington, D.C. Mayor Vincent C. Gray said Wednesday that local police and other public agencies will not cooperate with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to determine the immigration status of those they arrest. Immigration agent accused of pot smuggling in Ariz. - USA Today The 34-year-old U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent was charged with drug smuggling after a high-speed desert chase, during which he allegedly tossed marijuana bundles out of his government vehicle.

item.title: In the news this morning: Alabama immigrant workers hard to replace, detainee lawsuit alleges sexual abuse, 'birthers' and Marco Rubio, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Few Americans take immigrants' jobs in Alabama - The Washington Post A plan to hire unemployed Americans to replace the immigrant farm workers who have left the state after a strict new law took effect isn't working out; many of the American workers quit after a single day on the job. ACLU: Lawsuit alleges 3 immigrant women assaulted while in ICE custody - CNN A class-action lawsuit has been filed on behalf of three female immigrants who allege they were sexually assaulted while in U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement custody in Texas. AP Exclusive: Brewer touts immigration law in book - The Associated Press The Arizona governor who signed SB 1070 into law last year devotes much of her new book to defending the controversial anti-illegal immigration measure, describing it as a "fair, effective and necessary response." Documents Show FBI Targeted Communities Based On Race, Ethnicity - Talking Points Memo A just- released "massive trove of FBI documents" indicates that anti-Muslim training materials have spread within the bureau over several years, and that areas have been targeted based on race and ethnicity. Illegal immigrant attack on Mitt Romney persists - Politico More on this week's debate-night jab from Texas Gov. Rick Perry at former Massachusetts governor Mitt Romney over the latter's admission years ago that he unknowingly hired an undocumented worker. The Birthers' Next Target: Marco Rubio - Mother Jones "Birthers" who until recently tried to claim President Obama wasn't eligible for the presidency due to his Kenyan roots are now going after Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, a potential future GOP White House contender. Rubio has been under fire recently after it was revealed that his Cuban parents arrived in the U.S. earlier than he claimed.

item.title: In the news this morning: Obama seeking Latino support, AZ case against feds dismissed, Muslim workers fired over prayer break dispute, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Obama comes to Southern California seeking Latino support - Southern California Public Radio President Obama is back in Los Angeles today, raising money for his re-election campaign and trying to garner the support of Latino voters. Latino Republicans Find Party A Tough Sell - NPR President Obama has lost approval from Latino voters recently, but Latino voters haven't been embracing the GOP, either. Brewer's lawsuit over Obama immigration policy dismissed - Arizona Republic A U.S. District Court judge Friday dismissed Gov. Jan Brewer's lawsuit against the federal government over immigration enforcement, a countersuit to a federal lawsuit over SB 1070. The state lawsuit argued that the federal government  failed to protect Arizona from "invasion." Medical aid for illegal immigrants could haunt Mitt Romney - Los Angeles Times The state health care law that Mitt Romney signed in 2006 as governor of Massachusetts included a program known as the "Health Safety Net," which allows undocumented immigrants and other uninsured to get medical care. Worker says prayer break got her fired - CNN Muslim employees of the Hertz car rental chain at the Seattle-Tacoma airport were fired after not clocking out for prayer breaks. (Video)

item.title: In the news this morning: Long waits for legal immigration, fallout from Alabama law, controversy over E-Verify bill, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Immigrants find legal paths to U.S. long, difficult – USA Today Obtaining permanent legal resident status can take many years, even for professionals. It took one man profiled, a Peruvian-born television producer who speaks four languages, more than a decade. Illegal Immigrants Flee In Face Of New Laws, But To Where? - Neon Tommy Strict anti-illegal immigration state laws have caused immigrants to flee states like Arizona, Alabama, and Georgia. Experts say it’s impossible to track just where those who flee wind up. Will Alabama's Immigration Law Cause Short-term Hiccup or Long-term Heartache? - PBS NewsHour Alabama's new immigration law has caused a worker shortage, a farm industry crisis and school absences, among other things. Proponents say this is a hiccup, while others say the damage to the state will be long-term. DREAM Act-Eligible Man Faces Deportation, Despite Policy Change - Huffington Post Immigrants who came to the U.S. as children, like 25-year-old Shamir Ali of Miami, continue to land in deportation proceedings in spite of a federal deportation policy revision that could spare them. Alabama immigration law: Max's Deli owner in spotlight after supporting his legal employees - al.com Birmingham deli owner Steve Dubrinsky has "faced calls for a boycott from some patrons and a barrage of personal smears" after being quoted speaking in support of his workers in a local news story regarding the state's strict new immigration law. E-Verify briefing turns into shouting match - Southern California Public Radio A briefing for Capitol Hill staffers on a bill that would require employers to verify workers' status turned into a screaming match, with opponents calling the federal E-Verify database  "a flawed system rife with errors."

item.title: In the news this morning: Muslims call for policy reforms, judge orders Secure Communities memo released, Latinos and retirement, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Muslims call for reforms 10 years after Patriot Act - The Washington Post The report from Muslim civil rights advocates recommends policy changes, and accuses the FBI of religious profiling and spying on mosques using informants. Latinos Lagging On Retirement Savings, Says Pew - NPR Only 10 percent of the nation's 50.5 million Latinos have individual retirement accounts, according to the Pew Hispanic Center, compared with 35 percent of non-Latino whites. NY judge orders release of key document on immigration enforcement program by Nov. 1 - The Washington Post A U.S. district judge has given the federal government until Nov. 1 to turn over a memo to civil rights groups and immigrant advocates regarding whether the Secure Communities immigration enforcement program was optional through the beginning of 2010. S. Carolina immigration law will also affect legal residents - Fox News Latino A provision in the law that imposes fines of up to $5,000 for transporting an undocumented immigrant affects these immigrants' family members, including U.S. citizens. Can the GOP win the Latino vote? Does it matter? - CNN Is the lack of a clear message for Latino voters a problem for the Republican presidential hopefuls, or as expressed by some this week, do they not need one because these voters "want virtually exactly what everyone else wants?”

item.title: In the news this morning: Feds won't help Alabama implement state law, Asian American population growth, Halloween goes Latino, more
item.dc:creator: lberesteinrojas
item.content:encoded: Napolitano to Congress: Feds not helping Alabama officials put state immigration law in place - The Washington Post Homeland Security secretary Janet Napolitano has told a House committee that federal officials will not help Alabama implement its stringent new state immigration law, which the federal government is challenging in court.
